Paulo Siqueira}} |inkers = {{collapsible list|'''Vol. 1:'''
Craig Yeoung

Scott Hanna}} |letterers = |colorists = {{collapsible list|'''Vol. 1–2:'''
Laura Martin
'''Vol. 2:'''
Ian Herring
Rachelle Rosenberg}} |editors = |creative_team_month = |creative_team_year = |creators_series = |CEheader = |TPB = |ISBN = |TPB# = |ISBN# = |nonUS = }} {{italic title}}'''''A-Force''''' was an [[ongoing series|ongoing]] [[comic book]] series published by [[Marvel Comics]] that debuted in May 2015 as a part of Marvel's "[[Secret Wars (2015 comic book)|Secret Wars]]" [[Fictional crossover|crossover storyline]]. The series, created by writers [[G. Willow Wilson]] and [[Marguerite Bennett]] and artist [[Jorge Molina (comics)|Jorge Molina]], features Marvel's first all-female team of [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]]. The team first appeared as part of an [[Parallel universe (fiction)|alternate universe]] during "Secret Wars" but later reemerged in [[Earth-616|Marvel's primary continuity]]. ''A-Force'' ended in October 2016 due to poor sales despite favorable reviews from critics and was described as being "decidedly [[Feminism|feminist]]". ==Publication history== In February 2015, [[Marvel Comics]] announced that they would launch ''A-Force'' in May 2015. The series, written by [[G. Willow Wilson]] (''[[Ms. Marvel (Kamala Khan)|Ms. Marvel]]'') and Marguerite Bennett (''[[Angela (comics)|Angela: Asgard's Assassin]]'') and drawn by [[Jorge Molina (comics)|Jorge Molina]] (''[[X-Men (comic book)|X-Men]]''), features Marvel's first all-female team of [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]]. The team, led by [[She-Hulk]], initially consists of [[Dazzler (Marvel Comics)|Dazzler]], [[Medusa (comics)|Medusa]], [[Nico Minoru]] and Singularity, a new "[[Cosmic entity (Marvel Comics)|cosmic]] powered" hero, but features many more characters.{{cite web |last=Dickey |first=Josh |date=2015-02-06 |title=Marvel assembles first all-female Avengers team, the 'A-Force'|url=http://mashable.com/2015/02/06/marvel-female-avengers-a-force/|publisher=[[Mashable]]|accessdate=2015-02-05}} Wilson stated that Marvel editor Daniel Ketchum mandated that the team be composed entirely of female characters, but gave the writers total discretion when it came to which women to choose.{{cite web |last=Arrant |first=Chris |date=2015-02-06 |title=MARVEL Announces All-Female Avengers Team -- A-FORCE|url=http://www.newsarama.com/23459-marvel-announces-all-female-avengers-team-a-force.html|publisher=[[Newsarama]]|accessdate=2015-02-05}} Ketchum also brought in Bennett, whom he worked with on ''[[Nightcrawler (comics)|Nightcrawler]]'', to co-write the series with Wilson.{{cite web |last=Richards |first=Dave |date=2015-02-20 |title=Bennett Assembles Battleworld's Mightiest Heroes in "A-Force"|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=59441 |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]]|accessdate=2015-02-20}} The series takes place within Marvel's 2015 "[[Secret Wars (2015 comic book)|Secret Wars]]" [[crossover fiction|crossover storyline]], which finds the entire [[Marvel Universe]], including the Avengers, disbanded. What is left is a patchwork of different environments and on one such environment called Arcadia, which Wilson describes as a "feminist paradise", a familiar threat arises that forces A-Force to come together.{{cite web |last=Truitt |first=Brian |date=2015-02-06 |title=Female Avengers team comes to the fore with 'A-Force'|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/2015/02/06/marvel-comics-a-force-female-avengers/22970157/|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=2015-02-05}} Bennett elaborated,
It's this world where the Marvel heroines are leaders in their own civilization. I really didn't want to have some kind of validating reason... So I didn't want to do anything like, "all the men disappeared years ago" or "ever since all the menfolk were killed in that war" or something like that. There are men—there are heroes there. You'll see familiar faces and favorites, but the heroines are in charge, by majority. It's just this is how their world evolved. They were competent. They were clever and they were the ones in charge because of their skills and they were the best fit for these roles and demands of their world.
About the roster Wilson said, "We've purposefully assembled a team composed of very different characters—from disparate parts of the [[Marvel Universe|Marvel U]], with very different power sets, identities and ideologies. They'll all have to come together to answer some big questions: What would you sacrifice to succeed? What is being a hero worth?"{{cite web |last=White |first=Brett |date=2015-02-06 |title=Marvel Announces Female-led 'A-Force' From Wilson, Bennett, Molina |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=59095 |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=2015-02-05}} Wilson elaborated:
This an opportunity to put people who would normally have no reason to interact with each other on one team... I want people whose power sets really build on each other so that there are specific limitations that can only become overcome by working together. Nobody's so overpowered that it gets boring and nobody's so underpowered that they have to be saved all the time. I wanted a balance visually and practically... What's also going to be interesting is working out the power structure of the group. You have several people on it who are used to being either their own bosses or in a leadership position, and all of a sudden they're together.
Bennett explained that although the team features a broader roster, Dazzler, Medusa, She-Hulk, Singularity and Nico Minoru make up the core members. Bennett stated that she found Dazzler's optimism to be the most interesting explaining, "It's really hard to write a dark and dire book if you've got Dazzler there beside you." Regarding the dynamic between Medusa and She-Hulk, Bennett said,
They're both leaders and there's a lot of conflict between them. They are very supportive of one another when operating against a third party, but they also disagree with how things should be handled when it comes to crises. Medusa is monarchy; She-Hulk is democracy. Medusa is the right of queens and She-Hulk is the rule of law. She-Hulk is much more balanced than Medusa. It's the two of them playing off of their strengths and sometime playing off of each other for both necessary good and necessary evil.
The series also introduces a new character named Singularity, a [[pocket universe]] that gains self-consciousness during "Secret Wars". Wilson likened Singularity to [[Q (Star Trek)|Q]] from ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' and said, "Her entire existence is so unlike that of ours that she really has to learn about what we think of as being an individual and having an identity from the ground up, with no point of access except those she meets." Wilson also stated that Singularity can act as "a whole world within herself and she can also move between different worlds and dimensions like taking a walk, so she has access to all corners of the Marvel U in a way that other characters do not." "[Nico Minoru is] one of the first people we have encounter Singularity," Bennett revealed. "So Nico is put in charge of acclimating this character and showing her their civilization and world while trying to save it. Nico is sort of like the grounding human force and the anchor that begins to show Singularity the capacity of human beings, both for good and for evil, so Nico becomes even more invested when she starts to see her homeland through the eyes of this stranger." At the 2015 [[Chicago Comic & Entertainment Expo]], Marvel announced that ''A-Force'' would continue into [[All-New, All-Different Marvel]], the next phase of Marvel Universe after the end of "Secret Wars", with a second volume.{{cite web |last=Arrant |first=Chris |date=2015-04-24 |title=Report: Marvel Talks Post-SECRET WARS, A-FORCE As 'Lead' Book & Return of CAPTAIN AMERICA: WHITE |url=http://www.newsarama.com/24285-marvel-announcements-at-c2e2-retailer-breakfast.html |publisher=[[Newsarama]] |accessdate=2015-06-03}} Wilson said, "After 'Secret Wars', things don't go back to status quo. There [are] long-term repercussions for what has happened in Battleworld. What the aftermath of ''Secret Wars'' is for all of those characters who were together in Arcadia who are now waking up in the Marvel Universe… I'm not going to say. But they're going to have to deal probably more directly with those repercussions than any of the other teams in the aftermath of ''Secret Wars''."{{cite web |last=Morse |first=Ben |date=2015-05-20 |title=Secret Wars Correspondence: A-Force |url=http://marvel.com/news/comics/24636/secret_wars_correspondence_a-force |publisher=Marvel.com |accessdate=2015-06-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150526221827/http://marvel.com/news/comics/24636/secret_wars_correspondence_a-force |archive-date=2015-05-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }} In January 2016, Marvel announced that writer [[Kelly Thompson]], who co-wrote ''A-Force'' vol. 2, #2,{{cite web|last1=Gerding|first1=Stephen|title="Vader Down" Concludes, Deadpool 2099 Debuts & More Marvel January Highlights|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/article/vader-down-concludes-deadpool-2099-debuts-more-marvel-january-highlights|publisher=Comic Book Resources|date=2015-10-20|accessdate=2016-01-15}} will take over the series with artist [[Ben Caldwell (cartoonist)|Ben Caldwell]] starting with issue 5. Thompson stated that while she respects the way Wilson built the team, in a world where women are the primary heroes, she does not intend on making stories that are "unique to women". Thompson explained, "It's a comic about super heroes saving the day, plain and simple, and I approach writing them like I would writing anyone. These ladies are heroes just like any of their male colleagues." {{cite web|last1=Grauso|first1=Alisha|title=A-Force Gets New Recruits|url=http://marvel.com/news/comics/25632/a-force_gets_new_recruits|publisher=Marvel.com|date=2015-01-15|accessdate=2015-01-15}} In August 2016, ''A-Force'' tied into the "[[Civil War II]]" storyline beginning with issue #8. About the crossover, Thompson said, "There's no way, with our cast, that we weren't going to get drawn into it – Carol is obviously the big co-star of "Civil War II" and both Medusa and She-Hulk are poised to play big roles too. But I think we've got a really great ''A-Force'' story that ties directly to the event but will also stand on its own nicely. Because of the intricacies of "Civil War II" the ideas behind the event really pull our team apart – so what we're doing is a very personal and emotional gut punch of a story for these ladies who were sort of just getting started as friends and as a team."{{cite web |last=Marston |first=George |date=2016-05-02 |title=CIVIL WAR II Packs 'Emotional Gut Punch' For A-FORCE |url=http://www.newsarama.com/29087-civil-war-ii-packs-an-emotional-gut-punch-for-a-force.html |publisher=[[Newsarama]] |accessdate=2016-05-03}} In October 2016, a day before the release of issue #10, it was reported that ''A-Force'' was "effectively cancelled" after no new issues were listed among Marvel's November, December, or January solicitations. The report came despite Thompson's intentions to continue the series after "Civil War II" with a storyline that involved an "unspecified A-lister". Sales of ''A-Force'' had fallen by 79% since its debut with issue #1 selling 114,528 copies and issue #9 selling 23,484 copies.{{cite web |last=Arrant |first=Chris |date=2016-10-18 |title=Marvel's A-FORCE Axed ... Apparently |url=http://www.newsarama.com/31604-marvel-s-a-force-axed.html |publisher=[[Newsarama]] |accessdate=2016-10-18}} However in a letter written to the fans in the back pages of ''A-Force #10'', Thompson described it as "short hiatus" followed by an editorial note disclaiming that ''A-Force'' will be back and that fans may speed up its return by emailing Marvel.{{cite web |last=Johnston |first=Rich |date=2016-10-19 |title=Kelly Thompson Says Goodbye To A-Force |url=http://www.bleedingcool.com/2016/10/19/kelly-thompson-says-goodbye-force/ |publisher=[[Bleeding Cool]] |accessdate=2016-10-20}} ==Plot== ===Secret Wars=== A-Force, the defenders of the matriarchal [[Battleworld]] nation of Arcadia, responds to a [[megalodon]] attack while on routine patrol. During the attack, [[Miss America (America Chavez)|America Chavez]] throws the shark across the Shield, the wall that separates their borders, thus breaking the laws of [[Doctor Doom|Emperor Doom]] and is subsequently arrested by Doom's enforcers, the Thor Corps. Despite appeals from [[She-Hulk]], the baroness of Arcadia, Chavez is sentenced to spend the rest of her life on the wall. In response, She-Hulk tasks the Sub-Mariners - [[Namor]], [[Namorita]], and [[Namora]] - to find the source of the megalodon attack. Meanwhile, [[Nico Minoru]], lamenting the loss of Chavez, comes across a mysterious figure that fell out of the sky.{{cite comic |writer=Bennett, Marguerite; Wilson, G. Willow |penciller=Molina, Jorge|inker=Molina, Jorge; Yeung, Craig |colorist=Martin, Laura; Milla, Matt |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Ketchum, Daniel |title=A-Force |volume=1 |issue=1 |date=May 2015 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} The Sub-Mariners discover a strange portal in the ocean's depths but it implodes as they draw near. Later, at the behest of [[Loki (comics)|Loki]], Minoru introduces her new friend to She-Hulk. When [[Medusa (comics)|Medusa]] accuses the stranger, a sentient [[pocket universe]], of creating the portal, a [[Sentinel (comics)|sentinel]] falls from another portal and attacks the team. During the fight, the newcomer saves [[Dazzler (Marvel Comics)|Dazzler]] and convinces She-Hulk that she is not the cause. After destroying the sentinel, She-Hulk decides to travel through the still open portal and investigate the source herself.{{cite comic |writer=Bennett, Marguerite; Wilson, G. Willow |penciller=Molina, Jorge |inker=Yeung, Craig; Wong, Walden |colorist=Martin, Laura |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Ketchum, Daniel |title=A-Force |volume=1 |issue=2 |date=July 2015 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} She-Hulk arrives in a post-apocalyptic Manhattan and after a brief encounter with more sentinels, she is chased back to Arcadia by the Thor Corps. The Thor Corps follow in pursuit, but Medusa manages to repel them back into the portal and is killed in the process. When the Thor Corps return, She-Hulk alerts the citizens of Arcadia that there is a traitor in their midst that is spreading discontent and vows to bring them to justice as she and other A-Forcers go into hiding inside the newcomer.{{cite comic |writer=Bennett, Marguerite; Wilson, G. Willow |penciller=Molina, Jorge |inker=Molina, Jorge; Yeung, Craig |colorist=Martin, Laura |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Ketchum, Daniel |title=A-Force |volume=1 |issue=3 |date=August 2015 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} The newcomer smuggles A-Force outside the city. There, She-Hulk realizes that the portals' energy is of [[Asgard (comics)|Asgardian]] origin and they deduce that the traitor is Loki. With A-Force outlawed, Loki is set to be crowned the new baroness of Arcadia but is preemptively attacked by A-Force. After Loki is defeated, she releases a final blast of energy that breaches the Shield thus allowing the [[Marvel Zombies|zombie horde]] on the other side to enter.{{cite comic |writer=Bennett, Marguerite; Wilson, G. Willow |penciller=Molina, Jorge |inker=Yeung, Craig; Wong, Walden |colorist=Martin, Laura |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Ketchum, Daniel |title=A-Force |volume=1 |issue=4 |date=September 2015 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} As the horde approaches, She-Hulk rallies A-Force, the Thor Corps and other heroes in defense of Arcadia. During the fight, the zombies begin to overwhelm the city but the newcomer – now named Singularity – absorbs the entire horde, sacrificing herself in the process. In the aftermath of the battle, the Thor Corps arrests Loki as A-Force begins reconstruction of Arcadia. Meanwhile, She-Hulk comforts Minoru, who is still mourning the loss of her friends, telling her that she believes Singularity lives on.{{cite comic |writer=Bennett, Marguerite; Wilson, G. Willow |artist=Molina, Jorge |colorist=Martin, Laura |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Ketchum, Daniel |title=A-Force |volume=1 |issue=5 |date=October 2015 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} ===All-New, All-Different Marvel=== Following the conclusion of ''Secret Wars'', Singularity awakes in the primary [[Earth-616]] universe and quickly spots [[Carol Danvers]] but Danvers does not recognize her. Unbeknownst to Singularity, she is being pursued by a similar being named Antimatter. While Danvers confronts Antimatter, Singularity flees to New York City. With Antimatter still in pursuit, Singularity locates She-Hulk, who does not remember her either, and asks for help. As the pair fight Antimatter, Medusa arrives with reinforcements and takes Singularity into custody.{{cite comic |writer=Wilson, G. Willow |artist=Molina, Jorge |colorist=Martin, Laura |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Ketchum, Daniel; Kubert, Katie |title=A-Force |volume=2 |issue=1 |date=January 2016 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} After Antimatter kills one of Medusa's soldiers, she releases Singularity and teleports Antimatter to the moon. Realizing that physical attacks are having little effect on Antimatter, Singularity transports She-Hulk, Medusa and herself to Japan to seek the help of Minoru. When Antimatter returns, Minoru casts a spell that causes him to be temporarily unmade. The spell buys the women some time during which Danvers suggests that Antimatter maybe susceptible to intense levels of light particles. They then travel to Miami to recruit Dazzler just as Antimatter remerges.{{cite comic |writer=Thompson, Kelly; Wilson, G. Willow |artist=Molina, Jorge |colorist=Martin, Laura |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Kubert, Katie |title=A-Force |volume=2 |issue=2 |date=February 2016 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} Dazzler hits Antimatter with everything she has to no avail but it gives Danvers time to activate a containment device that she designed. When Antimatter overloads the device, Singularity has Minoru remove Antimatter's tracking ability and transports the team to [[S.W.O.R.D. (comics)|The Peak]]. As Antimatter eventually reaches The Peak, She-Hulk orders Singularity to stay behind while the rest of the team leaves to parley with Antimatter. After talks fail, Antimatter fatally wounds Dazzler and in turn She-Hulk decapitates Antimatter. Angered by Dazzler's death, Singularity leaves to confront a recovered Antimatter one-on-one.{{cite comic |writer=Thompson, Kelly; Wilson, G. Willow |artist=Molina, Jorge |colorist=Milla, Matt |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Kubert, Katie |title=A-Force |volume=2 |issue=3 |date=March 2016 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} As Singularity fights Antimatter, Dr. Tempest Bell, The Peak's lead scientist, develops a bomb capable of destroying Antimatter but denoting it will also kill Singularity. She-Hulk, Minoru and Danvers go to reinforce Singularity, while Medusa places the bomb inside Antimatter. Just as the bomb explodes, a revived Dazzler arrives with a dimensional teleporter and whisks Singularity away from the blast. With Antimatter destroyed, the team celebrates at a diner when Singularity senses a disturbance as remnants of Antimatter tear open portals to other worlds.{{cite comic |writer=Thompson, Kelly; Wilson, G. Willow |artist=Molina, Jorge |colorist=Martin, Laura |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Kubert, Katie |title=A-Force |volume=2 |issue=4 |date=April 2016 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} In [[Astoria, Oregon]], A-Force tracks a dragon from Battleworld named Countess and discover that she is being pursued by an alternate version of Dazzler that belonged to the Thor Corps. A-Force joins Dazzler Thor in combat which causes Countess to retreat. As the heroes wait for Countess's return, Dazzler confides to Dazzler Thor that she has been infected by the [[Terrigen Mist]] and is dying. When Countess arrives, she takes control of Minoru who then incapacitates the team.{{cite comic |writer=Thompson, Kelly |artist=Caldwell, Ben |colorist=Herring, Ian |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Kubert, Katie |title=A-Force |volume=2 |issue=5 |date=May 2016 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} She-Hulk, Medusa, Dazzler, Dazzler Thor, and Danvers awake in a jail cell in Astoria to discover that their powers are gone and the populace under the control of the Countess. After She-Hulk taunts the Countess, she has Minoru turn She-Hulk against the others. As the fight with She-Hulk takes the team away from the city and their powers return, the Countess has Minoru turn their feet into [[cement shoes]] and drag them under water.{{cite comic |writer=Thompson, Kelly |penciller=Caldwell, Ben |inker=Hanna, Scott |colorist=Herring, Ian |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Kubert, Katie |title=A-Force |volume=2 |issue=6 |date=June 2016 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} As the team is about to drown, Minoru commands them to breathe. Once out of the water, She-Hulk sends half the team to distract Countess, while the others rescue Minoru. After being rescued, Minoru reveals the true nature of Countess' powers and returns with Dazzler and Dazzler Thor to confront Countess. Minoru convinces Countess to have a change of heart as Dazzler Thor succumbs to the compounded effects that the Terrigen Mist are having on her otherworldly system. After Dazzler Thor's body vanishes, Dazzler warns her teammates that she may suffer a similar fate.{{cite comic |writer=Thompson, Kelly |penciller=Caldwell, Ben |inker=Hanna, Scott |colorist=Herring, Ian |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Kubert, Katie |title=A-Force |volume=2 |issue=7 |date=July 2016 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} ===Civil War II=== After She-Hulk is gravely wounded in a battle with [[Thanos]] during the ''[[Civil War II]]'' storyline, Danvers tells Minoru that the Inhuman [[Ulysses (comics)#Ulysses Cain|Ulysses]] had a vision of her killing a woman named Alice. Refusing to be arrested for a crime that she has yet to commit, Minoru flees to a safehouse in [[Ouray, Colorado]]. Unbeknownst to Minoru, the town is under attack from a swarm of giant bugs and encounters [[Elsa Bloodstone]]. Bloodstone informs Minoru that the attack is the result of an infection that is turning the populace into insects and takes her to meet Janine, whose daughter Alice has gone missing during the commotion. Meanwhile, Danvers and Medusa race to find Minoru before Dazzler and Singularity, who disagree with their methods.{{cite comic |writer=Thompson, Kelly |artist=Siqueira, Paulo |colorist=Rosenberg, Rachelle |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Kubert, Katie |title=A-Force |volume=2 |issue=8 |date=August 2016 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} Danvers and Medusa find Minoru and Bloodstone just before Dazzler and Singularity arrive. After a brief confrontation, they agree to split into two teams: one to find Alice and the other to protect the civilians. While searching for Alice in an abandoned mine, Danvers, Minoru and Bloodstone are attacked by a giant bug. The bug incapacitates Danvers and Bloodstone before telepathically communicating to Minoru that she is Alice and has been inadvertently infecting the townspeople after her transformation. Alice tells Minoru that killing her is the only way to save the people. When Minrou refuses, an infected Bloodstone threatens to kill Danvers.{{cite comic |writer=Thompson, Kelly |artist=Siqueira, Paulo |colorist=Rosenberg, Rachelle |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Kubert, Katie |title=A-Force |volume=2 |issue=9 |date=September 2016 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} Medusa, Singularity, and an infected Dazzler are overrun by bugs and regroup with the others just as Bloodstone infects Danvers. After Dazzler infects Medusa, Minoru casts a spell to transform Alice back into a human but it does not cure the rest of the populace. Alice explains that she must be killed and Minoru reluctantly casts a death spell on Alice which transforms the infected back into humans. Alice then remerges in her final form and tells A-Force that she is no longer a threat as she now has greater control of her powers. When the commotion is over, Danvers and Minoru continue to disagree over each other's actions but agree to visit She-Hulk together in the hospital.{{cite comic |writer=Thompson, Kelly |artist=Siqueira, Paulo; Bennet, Joe |colorist=Rosenberg, Rachelle |letterer=Petit, Cory |editor=Kubert, Katie |title=A-Force |volume=2 |issue=10 |date=October 2016 |publisher=Marvel Comics}} Arcadia. |- |colspan="2"|Singularity ||Sacrifices herself in ''A-Force'' #5. |- ||[[Nico Minoru|Sister Grimm]] ||Nico Minoru || |- ||[[Monica Rambeau|Spectrum]] ||Monica Rambeau || |- ||[[Spider-Woman (Jessica Drew)|Spider-Woman]] ||Jessica Drew || |- ||[[Spider-Woman (Gwen Stacy)|Spider-Woman]] ||[[Gwen Stacy]] || |- ||[[Storm (Marvel Comics)|Storm]] ||Ororo Munroe || |- |colspan="2"|[[Emma ||Wanda Maximoff || |- ||[[Anya Corazon|Spider-Girl]] ||Anya Corazon || |- ||[[Squirrel Girl]] ||Doreen Green || |- ||[[Sharon Carter|Agent 13]] ||Sharon Carter |rowspan="27"|''A-Force'' vol. 1 #5 (October 2015) || |- ||[[Angela (comics)|Angela]] ||Angela Odinsdottir || |- ||[[Armor (comics)|Armor]] ||Hisako Ichiki || |- ||[[Black Cat (Marvel Comics)|Black Cat]] ||Felicia Hardy || |- |colspan="2"|[[Clea]] || |- |colspan="2"|[[Karolina Dean]] || |- ||[[Domino (comics)|Domino]] ||Neena Thurman || |- ||[[Dust (comics)|Dust]] ||Sooraya Qadir || |- |colspan="2"|[[Elektra (comics)|Elektra Natchios]] || |- ||[[Enchantress (Marvel Comics)|Enchantress]] ||Amora || |- ||[[Firestar (Marvel Comics)|Firestar]] ||Angelica Jones || |- |colspan="2"|[[Molly Hayes]] || |- ||[[Jubilee (comics)|Jubilee]] ||Jubilation Lee || |- ||[[M (comics)|M]] ||Monet St. Croix || |- ||[[Dani Moonstar|Mirage]] ||Dani Moonstar || |- ||[[Mockingbird (Marvel Comics)|Mockingbird]] ||Bobbi Morse || |- ||[[Moondragon]] ||Heather Douglas || |- ||[[Psylocke]] ||Betsy Braddock || |- ||[[Pepper Potts|Rescue]] ||Pepper Potts || |- ||[[Rogue (comics)|Rogue]] ||Anna Marie || |- ||[[Kitty Pryde|Shadowcat]] ||Kitty Pryde || |- ||[[Snowbird (comics)|Snowbird]] ||Narya || |- ||[[Cassandra Lang|Stature]] ||Cassandra Lang || |- ||[[Tigra]] ||Greer Grant || |- ||[[X-23]] ||Laura Kinney || |- |colspan="2"|[[Mariko Yashida]] || |- |colspan="2"|[[Gertrude Yorkes]] || |} ===Post-Secret Wars=== {| class="wikitable collapsible" style="width:75%; text-align:left; margin:1em auto 1em auto;" |- !width=17%| Character !width=17%| Real name !width=26%| Joined in !width=40%| Notes |- ||'''[[Carol Danvers|Captain Marvel]]''' ||Carol Danvers |rowspan="4"|''A-Force'' vol. 2 #1 (January 2016) || |- ||'''[[Medusa (comics)|Medusa]]''' ||Medusalith Amaquelin Boltagon || |- ||'''[[She-Hulk]]''' ||Jennifer Walters || |- |colspan="2"|'''[[Singularity (comics)|Singularity]]''' || |- ||'''[[Dazzler (Marvel Comics)|Dazzler]]''' ||Alison Blaire |rowspan="2"|''A-Force'' vol. 2 #2 (February 2016) || |- |colspan="2"|'''[[Nico Minoru]]''' || |- ||[[Dazzler (Marvel Comics)|Dazzler Thor]] ||Alison Blaire ||''A-Force'' vol. 2 #5 (May 2016) ||Dies in ''A-Force'' vol. 2 #7 (July 2016) |} ==Critical reaction== ===Secret Wars=== {| class="wikitable infobox" style="float: right; width:24.2em; font-size: 80%; text-align: center; margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em; padding:0;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" ! colspan="4" style="font-size:120%;" |Professional reviews |- ! style="background:#d1dbdf;font-size:120%;" {{!}} ! style="background:#d1dbdf;font-size:120%;" {{!}} [[Comic Book Resources|CBR]] ! style="background:#d1dbdf;font-size:120%;" {{!}} [[IGN]] ! style="background:#d1dbdf;font-size:120%;" {{!}} [[Newsarama]] {{!}}- ! Issue ! colspan="3" |Rating |- | 1 | {{Rating|4.5|5}} | 8.4/10 | 8/10 |- | 2 | {{Rating|4|5}} | 8/10 | 8/10 |- | 3 | {{Rating|3.5|5}} | 7.3/10 | 8/10 |- | 4 | {{Rating|3|5}} | 6.8/10 | 7/10 |- | 5 | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} |} Greg McElhatton of [[Comic Book Resources]] (CBR) gave ''A-Force'' #1 four-and-a-half stars out of five writing, "''A-Force'' #1 is a triumph, taking a concept that could have simply been dashed off and then ignored and turning it into a book that I'd cheerfully read every month."{{cite web |last=McElhatton |first=Greg |date=2015-05-20 |title=A-Force #1 |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/comic-review/a-force-1-marvel-comics |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=2015-05-22}} Tony Guerrero of [[Comic Vine]] gave it four out of five stars saying, "This book was pretty much exactly what I wanted and hoped for. Too many times the female heroes in the Marvel Universe get overlooked. Marguerite Bennett and G. Willow Wilson have created a natural feeling world. It's easy to cry out that having just female heroes is a gimmick but it all simply works here."{{cite web |last=Guerrero |first=Tony |date=2015-05-19 |title=A-Force #1 Review |url=http://www.comicvine.com/reviews/a-force-1/1900-4119/ |publisher=[[Comic Vine]] |accessdate=2015-05-22}} Jesse Schedeen of [[IGN]] gave the issue an 8.4 out of 10 and said, "While certain details regarding the nature of this team and their connection to the old marvel Universe remain unclear, A-Force #1 marks a worthy debut for Marvel's newest team book."{{cite web |last=Schedeen |first=Jesse |date=2015-05-20 |title=A-Force #1 Review |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/05/21/a-force-1-review |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=2015-05-22}} Eric Diaz of [[The Nerdist]] gave it three out of five burritos and wrote, "Overall the issue was fine, and I'm curious to see where it all goes, but I'm far more eager to see what can be done with this grouping of awesome female heroes once the wacky conceit of Secret Wars is over and they return to the Marvel Universe proper." Diaz also noted that, "[Marvel is] making a decidedly feminist statement by taking nearly all of their major female heroes and putting them together in their own Avengers title called ''A-Force''."{{cite web |last=Diaz |first=Eric |date=2015-05-19 |title=Review: Marvel’s A-FORCE #1 |url=http://nerdist.com/review-marvels-a-force-1/ |publisher=[[The Nerdist]] |accessdate=2015-05-22}} Lan Pitts of [[Newsarama]] gave it an 8 out of 10 praising the artwork of Jorge Molina, [[Laura Martin]] and Matt Milla.{{cite web |last=Pitts |first=Lan |date=2015-05-19 |title=Best Shots Advance Reviews: A-FORCE #1, PLANET HULK #1, SPIDER-VERSE #1 |url=http://www.newsarama.com/24557-best-shots-advance-reviews-a-force-1-planet-hulk-1-spider-verse-1.html |publisher=[[Newsarama]] |accessdate=2015-05-22}} Doug Zawisza of CBR gave issue #2 four stars, writing "''A-Force'' #2 appears to be a straightforward superheroine adventure on the surface but, as the pages turn, Bennett, Wilson, Molina, Yeung, Wong, Martin and Petit make it quite clear this isn't a straightforward anything... Easily dismissed as a gimmick, ''A-Force'' is anything but, packing in strong characters, smart characterization and wonderful artwork."{{cite web |last=Zawisa |first=Doug |date=2015-07-03 |title=A-Force #2 |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/comic-review/a-force-2-marvel-comics |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=2015-07-06}} Jeff Lake of IGN gave it an 8, saying "The first issue of ''A-Force'' provided a fine mix of boisterous action and engaging character work, all of which effectively tied into the larger Battleworld picture. Issue #2 offers much of the same, G. Willow Wilson and Marguerite Bennett both focusing the direction of the main narrative as they expand their characters place within it."{{cite web |last=Lake |first=Jeff |date=2015-07-02 |title=Comic Book Reviews for July 1, 2015 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/07/02/comic-book-reviews-for-july-1-2015?page=2 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=2015-07-06}} Richard Gray of Newsarama also gave it an 8 and wrote, "With the introduction of a new heroine and a new threat, the issue skillfully plays to the strengths of the ensemble, from She-Hulk's natural leadership, Medusa's ruthless decision making and former Runaway Nico Minoru's compassion."{{cite web |last=Gray |first=Richard |date=2015-07-02 |title=Best Shots Reviews: DARTH VADER #7, MIDNIGHTER #2, 8HOUSE: ARCLIGHT #1, More |url=http://www.newsarama.com/25029-best-shots-reviews-darth-vader-7-midnighter-2-8house-arclight-1-more.html |publisher=[[Newsarama]] |accessdate=2015-07-06}} Marykate Jasper of CBR gave issue #3 three-and-a-half stars writing, "Altogether, ''A-Force'' still has a lot going for it, but the pacing is compounding the problems of its large cast. Luckily, issue #3 takes many of the necessary steps for ramping the pace back up, and I'm optimistic for issue #4."{{cite web |last=Jasper |first=Marykate |date=2015-08-17 |title=A-Force #3 |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/comic-review/a-force-3-marvel-comics |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=2015-08-18}} Lake gave it a 7.3, praising the artwork of Molina but criticizing the narrative restraints of the ''Secret Wars'' storyline but said, "Thankfully, this is one example where the book’s art is able to mask any narrative quibbles."{{cite web |last=Lake |first=Jeff |date=2015-08-13 |title=Comic Book Reviews for August 12, 2015 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/08/13/comic-book-reviews-for-august-12-2015?page=2 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=2015-08-14}} C.K. Stewart of Newsarama gave it an 8 saying, "''A-Force'' gets stronger with each passing issue, and the dramatic turns at the end of ''A-Force'' #3 make it the best issue yet."{{cite web |last=Stewart |first=C.K. |date=2015-08-13 |title=Best Shots Reviews: HOUSE OF M #1 (Advance), A-FORCE #3, BATMAN #43, More |url=http://www.newsarama.com/25541-best-shots-reviews-house-of-m-1-advance.html |publisher=[[Newsarama]] |accessdate=2015-08-14}} McElhatton gave issue #4 three stars writing, "While "A-Force" #4 is not a bad comic, Marguerite Bennett, G. Willow Wilson, Jorge Molina, Craig Yeung and Walden Wong's latest installment clearly tries to get a lot of the exposition onto the table as the plot gears up for next month's conclusion, and that original sense of wonder and newness is greatly diminished as a result."{{cite web |last=McElhatton |first=Greg |date=2015-09-11 |title=A-Force #4 |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/comic-review/a-force-4-marvel-comics |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=2015-09-13}} Levi Hunt of IGN gave it a 6.8 and said, "Jorge Molina's art is once again the best thing about ''A-Force'' as the series hits its least narratively satisfying issue. The underserved nature of the book’s development has led to a conflict that has few real emotional stakes."{{cite web |last=Hunt |first=Levi |date=2015-09-10 |title=Comic Book Reviews for September 9, 2015 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/09/10/comic-book-reviews-for-september-9-2015?page=2 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=2015-09-11}} David Pepose of Newsarama gave it a 7 saying, "It's a good thing this book looks so good, because the plot definitely feels flat, with the reveal of A-Force's traitor - and her endgame after being easily overcome - feels particularly undercooked."{{cite web |last=Pepose |first=David |date=2015-09-10 |title=Best Shots Rapid-Fire Reviews: A-FORCE #3, BATMAN #44, THE WICKED + THE DIVINE #14, CIVIL WAR #4, More |url=http://www.newsarama.com/25848-best-shots-rapid-fire-reviews-a-force-3-batman-44-the-wicked-+-the-divine-14-civil-war-4.html |publisher=[[Newsarama]] |accessdate=2015-09-11}} ===All-New, All-Different Marvel=== {| class="wikitable infobox" style="float: right; width:24.2em; font-size: 80%; text-align: center; margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em; padding:0;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" ! colspan="4" style="font-size:120%;" |Professional reviews |- ! style="background:#d1dbdf;font-size:120%;" {{!}} ! style="background:#d1dbdf;font-size:120%;" {{!}} [[Comic Book Resources|CBR]] ! style="background:#d1dbdf;font-size:120%;" {{!}} [[IGN]] ! style="background:#d1dbdf;font-size:120%;" {{!}} [[Newsarama]] {{!}}- ! Issue ! colspan="3" |Rating |- | 1 | {{Rating|3|5}} | 7.0/10 | 8/10 |- | 2 | {{n/a}} | 8.5/10 | 9/10 |- | 3 | {{Rating|3.5|5}} | 7.5/10 | 8/10 |- | 4 | {{Rating|4|5}} | 7.8/10 | {{n/a}} |- | 5 | {{Rating|4|5}} | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} |- | 6 | {{n/a}} | 7.3/10 | {{n/a}} |- | 7 | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} |} Greg McElhatton of CBR gave ''A-Force'' #1 three stars out of five writing, "Ultimately, I wish the narration from Singularity had been dropped entirely from "A-Force" #1. You can still understand what's going on without it, and the disparate clash of her thoughts and dialogue would have never happened. Hopefully, they will get smoothed out a bit in future issues, but—for now—this issue is only alright."{{cite web |last=McElhatton |first=Greg |date=2016-01-06 |title=A-Force #1 |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/comic-review/a-force-1-marvel-comics-2016 |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=2016-01-07}} Jeff Lake of IGN gave the issue a 7.0 out of 10 and said, "Overall, ''A-Force'' #1 is a solid, if unspectacular debut. It's great to see this cast together again, especially in the hands of Wilson, Molina and Martin, but as of now this new direction feels hamstrung by its need to square peg its way into a round hole."{{cite web |last=Lake |first=Jeff |date=2016-01-06 |title=A-Force #1 Review |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/01/07/a-force-1-review-2 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=2016-01-07}} David Pepose of [[Newsarama]] gave it an 8 out of 10 saying, "While this book starts off with a shaky foundation - namely, that you have to have read a ''Secret Wars'' tie-in to understand where Singularity came from - Wilson does a great job at firming things up, with her new heroine proving to be a fun addition to the Marvel Universe."{{cite web |last=Pepose |first=David |date=2016-01-06 |title=Best Shots Reviews: DR. STRANGE #4, SWAMP THING #1, A-FORCE #1 |url=http://www.newsarama.com/27426-best-shots-reviews-dr-strange-4-swamp-thing-1-a-force-1.html |publisher=[[Newsarama]] |accessdate=2016-01-07}} Lake gave issue #2 an 8.5 saying, "That's more like it. Following a passable but limited debut, ''A-Force'' takes a welcome leap courtesy of Kelly Thompson, G. Willow Wilson and Jorge Molina."{{cite web |last=Lake |first=Jeff |date=2016-02-04 |title=Comic Book Reviews for February 3, 2016 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/02/04/comic-book-reviews-for-february-3-2016?page=2 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=2016-02-09}} Justin Partridge of Newsarama gave it a 9 writing, "''A-Force'' #2 reads like a [[Sleater-Kinney]] song sounds: all confident bravado and a relentless pace. While the original series was inescapably tied to a company wide, Kelly Thompson, G. Willow Wilson, Jorge Molina and Laura Martin quickly cast off those ropes of continuity to let these ladies stand on their own and get down to the important work of punching weird stuff and giving each other sass."{{cite web |last=Partridge |first=Justin |date=2016-02-03 |title=Best Shots Reviews: DR. STRANGE #5, BATGIRL #48, DEJAH THORIS #1, More |url=http://www.newsarama.com/27816-best-shots-reviews-dr-strange-5-batgirl-48-dejah-thoris-1-more.html |publisher=[[Newsarama]] |accessdate=2016-02-09}} McElhatton gave ''A-Force'' #3 three-and-a-half stars writing, "''A-Force'' #3 feels like a turning point for this ongoing series. With the team fully solidified, Kelly Thompson, G. Willow Wilson and Jorge Molina begin to show readers just how these established characters will work together, even as the relatively new Singularity continues to establish herself. Bit by bit, that early potential we saw in the "Secret Wars" tie-in starts to bear fruit in ''A-Force'' #3."{{cite web |last=McElhatton |first=Greg |date=2016-03-07 |title=A-Force #3 |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/comic-review/a-force-3-marvel-comics-1 |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=2016-03-08}} Lake gave the issue a 7.5 saying, "Bucking the usual slow roll-out most super team books enjoy, ''A-Force'''s latest is again a high energy affair. Where last issue saw Kelly Thompson and G. Willow Wilson provide a welcome jump in character development and explored relationship dynamics, issue #3 offers a more action oriented focus."{{cite web |last=Lake |first=Jeff |date=2016-03-03 |title=Comic Book Reviews for March 2, 2016 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/03/03/comic-book-reviews-for-march-2-2016?page=2 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=2016-03-04}} Partridge gave it an 8 and said, "Writers Kelly Thompson and G. Willow Wilson continue the dazzling chemistry and tension between the team while at the same time keeping each woman's voice on point and selling Antimatter as a real threat to the team."{{cite web |last=Partridge |first=Justin |date=2016-03-03 |title=Best Shots Rapid-Fire Reviews: Spider-Man #2, Midnighter #10, Old Man Logan #3, More |url=http://www.newsarama.com/28238-best-shots-rapid-fire-reviews-spider-man-2-midnighter-10-old-man-logan-3-more.html |publisher=[[Newsarama]] |accessdate=2016-03-04}} Marykate Jasper of CBR gave issue #4 four stars writing, ''A-Force'' #4 gives readers the camaraderie, compassion and quips that they've come to love and expect from this series.{{cite web |last=Jasper |first=Marykate |date=2016-04-18 |title=A-Force #4 |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/comic-review/a-force-4-marvel-comics-1 |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=2016-04-18}} Lake gave it a 7.8 saying, "In just four short issues Kelly Thompson and G. Willow Wilson have crafted a team rife with unique personalities, in turn creating an undeniable chemistry between them that makes their unfolding adventures ones worth investing in. Issue #4 only solidifies that fact, the conclusion to the Antimatter arc resulting in plenty of great moments both joint and character specific."{{cite web |last=Lake |first=Jeff |date=2016-04-14 |title=Comic Book Reviews for April 13, 2016 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/04/14/comic-book-reviews-for-april-13-2016?page=2 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=2016-04-14}} McElhattan gave issue #5 four stars writing, "If ''A-Force'' #5 is any indication, the series is in good hands. Thompson, Caldwell and Herring's first issue together is fun and exciting, even as there are strong character and plot hooks to keep readers coming back for more."{{cite web |last=McElhatton |first=Greg |date=2016-05-05 |title=A-Force #5 |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/comic-review/a-force-5-marvel-comics |publisher=[[Comic Book Resources]] |accessdate=2016-05-06}} Lake gave issue #6 a 7.3 saying, "When it comes to ''A-Force'', the team's chemistry goes hand in hand with its success. Case in point – issue #6 is a solid, if unspectacular affair, with a familiar villain and a by the numbers plot. What makes the issue click is its fantastic characterization, writer Kelly Thompson continuing to build off of the great chemistry generated in the book's first arc."{{cite web |last=Lake |first=Jeff |date=2016-06-02 |title=Comic Book Reviews for June 1, 2016 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/06/02/comic-book-reviews-for-june-1-2016?page=2 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=2016-06-21}} ===Civil War II=== {| class="wikitable infobox" style="float: right; width:24.2em; font-size: 80%; text-align: center; margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em; padding:0;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" ! colspan="4" style="font-size:120%;" |Professional reviews |- ! style="background:#d1dbdf;font-size:120%;" {{!}} ! style="background:#d1dbdf;font-size:120%;" {{!}} [[Comic Book Resources|CBR]] ! style="background:#d1dbdf;font-size:120%;" {{!}} [[IGN]] ! style="background:#d1dbdf;font-size:120%;" {{!}} [[Newsarama]] {{!}}- ! Issue ! colspan="3" |Rating |- | 8 | {{n/a}} | 7.0/10 | {{n/a}} |- | 9 | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} |- | 10 | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} |} Jeff Lake of IGN gave issue #8 a 7.0 writing, Paulo Siqueira makes his mark as the new series artist, but ultimately this tie-in isn't quite possessing of the same charisma the series is known for.{{cite web |last=Lake |first=Jeff |date=2016-08-11 |title=Comic Book Reviews for August 10, 2016 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/08/11/comic-book-reviews-for-august-10-2016?page=2 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=2016-08-18}} ==Collected editions== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! width=25%| Title ! width=25%| Material collected ! width=25%| Publication date ! width=25%| ISBN |- || '''A-Force Vol. 0: Warzones!''' || ''A-Force'' #1-5 (''Secret Wars'') || December 1, 2015 || {{ISBNT|978-0785198611}} |- || '''A-Force Vol. 1: Hypertime''' || ''A-Force'' (2016) #1-4
''Avengers'' (2015) #0 (A-Force story)
''Avengers'' (1963) #83
''A-Force'' (2015) #1 || July 19, 2016 || {{ISBNT|978-0785196051}} |- || '''A-Force Vol. 2: Civil War II''' || ''A-Force'' #5-10 || January 17, 2017 || {{ISBNT|978-0785196068}} |} ==In other media== * An A-Force table was released as part of the "Women of Power" [[Downloadable content|DLC]] pack for ''[[Zen Pinball 2]]'' and ''[[Pinball FX2]]''.{{cite web |last= |first= |date=September 27, 2016 |title=Marvel's Women of Power Pinball Pack Hits Zen’s Pinball Platforms Today |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/pressreleases/282205/Marvels_Women_of_Power_Pinball_Pack_Hits_Zenrsquos_PinballPlatforms_Today.php |publisher=[[Gamasutra]] |accessdate=September 28, 2016}} and an event in the Avengers Academy App. ==See also== * [[List of feminist comic books]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Official website|http://marvel.com/comics/series/19245/a-force_2015_-_present}} {{Avengers}} {{Avengers publications}} {{She-Hulk}} [[Category:2015 comics debuts]] [[Category:2016 comics endings]] [[Category:Avengers (comics)]] [[Category:Comics about women]] [[Category:Comics spin-offs]] [[Category:Feminist comics]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Performance art]]; added [[Category:Performance art festivals]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]

revision.text:
[[File:Orquesta sinfónica nacional (Argentina).JPG|thumb|300px|The National Symphony Orchestra performs [[Gustav Mahler]]'s [[Symphony No. 2 (Mahler)|Symphony No. 2]] at the [[University of Buenos Aires]] Law School.]] The '''Argentine National Symphony Orchestra''' is the state symphony of [[Argentina]], and is based in [[Buenos Aires]].
==Overview==
Established as the State Symphony Orchestra, on November 20, 1948, via a bill (Law 35879) signed by President [[Juan Perón]], the orchestra was created that it could ''"constitute the pitch of universal resonance that our music needs, while providing the most effective means of popular education in the arts."'' <ref>[http://culturasinfonica.blogspot.com/2006/04/decreto-de-fundacin.html Cultura Sinfónica: Decreto de fundación] {{es icon}}</ref>
Philharmonic associations had, by then, a long tradition in Argentina, and could be traced in Buenos Aires to the 1822 formation of the Academy of Music and of the Philharmonic Association, the following year. These orchestras struggled under the instability prevailing during the years of the [[Confederación Argentina|Argentine Confederation]], however, and their performances were only sporadic. The [[German Argentine]] community helped advance the medium with the founding a number of [[choir|choral societies]] between 1852 and 1863, notably ''Concordia'', ''Germania'' and the ''Deutsche Sing-Akademie'', and these were complementted by the Buenos Aires Orchestral Society (1876) and the Musical Mutual Society (1894). The latter ultimately formed the first orchestral [[guild]] in Argentina, the Orchestra Professionals' Association (APO), in 1919.<ref name=history>[http://www.historiasinfonica.blogspot.com/ Historia Sinfónica] {{es icon}}</ref>
The APO Orchestra was constituted as such in 1922, and prospered with its colloaboration with the local [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]] Association, reaching its zenith under the baton of Swiss conductor [[Ernest Ansermet]]. The [[great depression]] later limited its activity sharply, and the orchestra was nearly closed in 1935, highlighting the need for state support. Accordingly, the Buenos Aires Symphony (today the [[Buenos Aires Philharmonic]]) was founded in 1947, and in 1948, the State Symphony Orchestra.<ref name=history/>
The symphony was created under the aegis of the Secretariat of Culture, and with 92 musicians. Directed initially by Roberto Kinsky, its first concert took place at the renowned [[Teatro Colón|Colón Opera House]] on November 30, 1949; on that evening's program was [[Ludwig van Beethoven]]'s ''[[Consecration of the House Overture]]'', [[Johannes Brahms]]'s [[Symphony No. 2 (Brahms)|Symphony No.2]], and [[Igor Stravinsky]]'s ''Scherzo Fantastico''. Its repertoire was soon expanded to include works by classical Argentine composers, as well, notably [[Carlos Guastavino]], [[Carlos López Buchardo]] and [[Alberto Williams]]. Apart from its performances at the Colón Opera House, the symphony would appear often in the [[Cervantes Theatre (Buenos Aires)|Cervantes]] and [[Teatro Gran Rex|Gran Rex]] theatres, and it increasingly featured [[20th-century classical music]], notably [[Ottorino Respighi]]'s ''Sinfonia Drammatica'' and [[Sergei Prokofiev]]'s ''[[Alexander Nevsky (Prokofiev)|Alexander Nevsky]]''; among the well-known guest musicians during the symphony's early years was violinist [[Henryk Szeryng]].<ref name=history/> [[File:Programa de la Sinfonica Nacional 1966.jpg|thumb|A playbill from 1966]] The [[Revolución Libertadora|1955 overthrow]] of President Juan Perón led to the State Symphony's reorganization as the Argentine National Symphony. Its first post-Perón conductor, former Colón Opera House Director [[Juan José Castro]], had returned from exile and took the baton to acclaim on November 11, leading the symphony in their performance of ''[[La Mer (Debussy)|La Mer]]'', by [[Claude Debussy]]. He worked to widen its appeal by incorporating works by contemporary composers such as [[Olivier Messiaen]], [[Paul Hindemith]], Igor Stravinsky and [[Béla Bartók]], and by securing guest conductors such as [[Willem van Otterloo]] and Igor Stravinsky, who conducted performances of his own works in 1960. Frustrated by bureaucratic tedium, however, Castro resigned in October.<ref name=history/> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Argentine National Symphony, Sheraton.jpg|left|thumb|240px|The National Symphony celebrates its 25th anniversary with a rooftop concert in 1974{{deletable image-caption|Tuesday, 22 November 2011}}]] -->
The symphony followed a more traditional line after Víctor Tevah's appointment as chief conductor in 1961, and the contemporary music programs were cancelled. Its itinerary was steeped up, and would include a successful tour of theatres in the Argentine hinterland as well as in [[Asunción, Paraguay]], in 1962. Highlights from this period included guest conductor [[Paul Klecki]]'s [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]] concert series and the rise to prominence of pianist [[Martha Argerich]]. Ongoing administrative disputes, however, took their toll, and the appointment of Teodoro Fuchs in March 1966 as its first full director since Castro met one the body's chief demands, though budget scarcities led to his resignation later that year.
The installation of a dictatorship under General [[Juan Carlos Onganía]] led to a marked influence of the [[Church-state relations in Argentina|Catholic Church]] over the repertoire, and its new director, Juan Carlos Zorzi, offered up mostly [[requiem]]s, [[mass (religion)|masses]] and [[te deum]]s, as well as frequent collaboratios with the [[Universidad Católica Argentina|Argentine Catholic University]]'s choir. The symphony performed at the reinauguation of the Cervantes Theatre, which had been nearly lost to a 1961 fire, in 1968, though the Onganía regime's continuing hostility to the symphony led to its being stripped of a formal home, and the body performed as a [[radio orchestra]]. Losing numerous musicians, Zorzi resigned, and though the 1970 appointment of Spanish conductor [[Jacques Bodmer]] as director was followed by a sponsorship from the Italian Embassy, lack of federal support kept the symphony on the brink of closure throughout 1971 and 1972.<ref>[http://culturasinfonica.blogspot.com/2006/04/carta-de-renuncia-de-juan-jose-castro.html Cultura Sinfónica: Juan José Castro] {{es icon}}</ref><ref>[http://www.clarin.com/diario/2006/06/04/espectaculos/c-01301.htm ''Clarín'': La Sinfónica, en la encrucijada] {{es icon}}</ref> The election of [[Peronist]] candidate [[Héctor Cámpora]] in 1973 brought with it restored support for the institution, including disbursement for a year's worth of unpaid salaries. A successful Beethoven series at the [[Luna Park, Buenos Aires|Luna Park Arena]] was followed by the 25th anniversary concert, November 29, 1974, memorable for its being held atop the [[Sheraton Buenos Aires Hotel & Convention Center|Buenos Aires Sheraton]] with a televised reprise of Roberto Kinsky's inaugural program. A renewed funding crisis led director Bodmer to return to [[Barcelona]] in July 1975, however, and his assistant, Jorge Fontenla, was appointed in his stead. Fontenla's replacement with Bruno D'Astoli in 1978 coincided with the symphony's eclipse by the Buenos Aires Philharmonic, which enjoyed the advantage of a permanent home at the Colón Opera House (while the symphony was relegated to Monday nights at the Cervantes). Its struggles helped result in the 1980 establishment of the Friends of the National Symphony, and though the end of the last dictatorship in 1983 brought with it high hopes, a conflict with the newly appointed general director, Iván Cosentino, resulted in a stoppage during the first half of 1985. Ongoing budgetary problems prompted the new director, Jorge Rotter, to schedule free concerts to the public every other Wednesday as a form of protest during 1987. A renewed crisis in 1990 led to his resignation and the suspension of activities.<ref name=history/>
Lacking a director, the symphony was supervised by the head of [[SADAIC]], [[José María Castiñeira de Dios]], who organized the symphony's first European performance (in [[Spain]]), and secured appointment of Simón Blech as director in late 1991. Another figure credited with shepherding the symphony through this difficult era was its former director, Juan Carlos Zorzi, who had served as interim director during the early 1980s and continued to influence the repertoire, including more works by Latin American composers such as [[Mexican music|Mexican composer]] [[Eduardo Diazmuñoz]], who led the symphony as guest conductor; Zorzi also took the baton for a tour of [[Chile]] in 1992. The appointment of Pedro Ignacio Calderón as chief conductor in 1996 was followed by a number of critics' awards and by the symphony's 50th anniversary celebrations in 1998, for which the body was invited to perform in [[Los Angeles]] and [[Tokyo]].<ref>[http://www.cultura.gov.ar/direcciones/?info=detalle&id=132&idd=1 Secretariat of Culture] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091012114258/http://www.cultura.gov.ar/direcciones/?info=detalle&id=132&idd=1 |date=October 12, 2009 }} {{es icon}}</ref> [[File:Pedro Ignacio Calderón & National Symphony.jpg|thumb|Maestro Pedro Ignacio Calderón and the symphony]]
Obtaining their first salary increase in thirteen years in 2006, the National Symphony Orchestra has persisted over often overwhelming odds, not the least of which has been its lack of a permanent home (unofficially located in the [[Cervantes Theatre (Buenos Aires)|Cervantes Theatre]]). Maintaining a loyal esprit de corps among its musicians, who have on numerous past occasions performed without pay, the symphony has also attracted figures of international stature on the classical music stage, including guest conductors [[Erich Kleiber]], Sir [[Georg Solti]], [[Ernest Ansermet]], [[Igor Markevitch]], [[Hermann Scherchen]], [[Sergiu Celibidache]], [[Rudolf Kempe]], [[Antal Dorati]], Sir [[Malcolm Sargent]], [[Hans Rosbaud]], [[Jean Fournet]], [[Igor Stravinsky]], [[Heitor Villa-Lobos]], [[Aram Katchaturian]], [[Frank Martin (composer)|Frank Martin]] and [[Pablo Casals]], as well as renowned guest soloists such as [[Arthur Rubinstein]], [[Ruggiero Ricci]], [[Nicanor Zabaleta]], [[Gyorgy Sandor]], Martha Argerich, [[Uto Ughi]], and [[Barry Douglas (musician)|Barry Douglas]].
Its need for an official home was addressed in 2006 with plans to create a concert hall for the symphony in the Bicentennial Cultural Center. The center's inaugural in the former [[Buenos Aires Central Post Office]], scheduled for the [[Argentina Bicentennial|Bicentennial]] in 2010,<ref>[http://212.145.146.10/ejercicio/concursos/inicio/060607a_bases.pdf Centro Cultural del Bicentenario. May 2006.] {{es icon}}</ref> was later delayed, and the Belgrano Auditorium became the symphony's temporary home.<ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1250613-el-esperado-regreso-de-la-sinfonica ''La Nación'': El esperado regreso de la Sinfónica] {{es icon}}</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.cultura.gov.ar/agenda/?info=detalle&id=1695 Secretariat of Culture: National Symphony Orchestra] ==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Argentine National Symphony Orchestra}} [[Category:Musical groups established in 1948]] [[Category:Symphony orchestras]] [[Category:Argentine music]] [[Category:Argentine culture]]

{{for|the film producer|Bruce A. Block}} '''Bruce Block''' (born April 13, 1967 in [[St. Joseph, Michigan]]) is an [[entertainer]], [[Illusionist|magician]], [[actor]], and [[ventriloquist]].
==Career== Block has appeared on ''[[America's Got Talent]]'' (seasons 2 and 3), ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' with [[Jay Leno]] and many more.<ref>[http://www.theoddballcomedyofbruceblock.com theoddballcomedyofbruceblock.com]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> His expertise is appreciated even by his peers. Scott Wells reviewed Block's appearance at the [[Texas Association of Magicians]] 2003 conference by stating "Bruce Block was perhaps the highlight of the evening...", His humor and juggling never missed..." and "Very clever and quite memorable".<ref name=wells>By Scott Wells, [http://www.taom.org/html/scott_wells_review.html taom.org] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724083650/http://www.taom.org/html/scott_wells_review.html |date=July 24, 2008 }}, review of the 2003 Texas Association Of Magicians conference, retrieved September 25, 2008</ref> Bruce Block holds the world record for most cigar boxes balanced on his chin.<ref>by Michael Ferguson, [http://www.juggle.org/archives/jugmags/36-4/36-4,p31.htm juggle.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080405212420/http://www.juggle.org/archives/jugmags/36-4/36-4%2Cp31.htm |date=April 5, 2008 }}, Winter 84-85, "Cigar Box Stack!", retrieved September 25, 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.juggling.org/jw/86/4/news.html juggling.org], Juggler's World: Juggler's World: Vol. 38, No. 4, "Guinness wants heavies and box-balancers", "A heated battle is going on between two cigar box balancers for the honor of appearing as the Guinness world champion in the category. Bruce Block's supremacy in the category is being challenged by Michael Toro of Sarasota, Fla...", retrieved September 25, 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.juggling.org/jw/87/3/tidbits.html juggling.org], Juggler's World: Vol. 39, No. 3, "Great enough for Guinness", "challenger Bruce Block unseated champion Michael Toro by balancing 134 boxes for the requisite five seconds", retrieved September 25, 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.tv.com/bill-nye-the-science-guy/balance/episode/241880/trivia.html?tag=episode_tabs;trivia tv.com]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, "Bill Nye: The Science Guy: Balance", under notes section: "Bruce Block set a record when he balanced 212 cigar boxes on his chin for 13.5 seconds in February 1990", retrieved September 25, 2008</ref>
His special acts include: *Escaping from a [[straitjacket]] *Lying on a bed of nails and having a lady jump on him *Ventriloquist act with his rabbit *Making his or someone else's head vanish *[[Juggling]] balls with his mouth *Making a miniature horse appear in a box *Balancing hundreds of cigar boxes on his chin
==Recognition== *In 2005, Bruce Block received the "Best of Las Vegas Award" from the ''[[Las Vegas Review Journal]]''.<ref>[http://www.reviewjournal.com/bestoflv/2005/LongReturns.jsp?bestID=7275 reviewjournal.com], Bruce Block, Best Magician 2005, retrieved September 25, 2008</ref> *February, 2005 - Bruce Block wins the $10,000 first prize on ''[[Steve Harvey's Big Time Challenge]]''<ref name=news>[http://www.bruceblockproductions.com/main.htm bruceblockproductions.com], "News page, retrieved September 25, 2008</ref> *In February 2005, Block's talking Rabbit "Skippy Ala King" made a surprise appearance at the [[Aspen Comedy Festival]] and was given the honor of "Best of the Festival".<ref name=news/>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{More footnotes|date=May 2014}} The '''Chacarera''' is a dance and music that originated in [[Santiago del Estero]], [[Argentina]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digital-daydreams.com/enc/world/show_country.php?id=5 |title=World Music - Argentina |website=Digital-daydreams.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-15}}</ref> It is a genre of [[folk music]] that, for many [[Argentina|Argentines]], serves as a rural counterpart to the cosmopolitan imagery of the [[tango (ballroom)|Tango]]. A dance form played by contemporary musicians as soloists or in small ensembles of voice, guitar, violin and bombo drum, the Chacarera is often legitimized by its “origin” in the remote province of [[Santiago del Estero]]. It is also the product of a romanticized construction of national identity projected by urban cultural institutions and disseminated through the mass media{{Citation needed|date=March 2016}}. A recent and very well known singer, [[Soledad Pastorutti]], made an important popularization across all Argentine provinces, during the 1990s, 2000s and 2010s.
==Chacarera music== While much of the Chacarera repertoire can be traced to the 1920s sheet music of Andrés Chazarreta (Chazarreta 1947[1916]), the contemporary Chacarera style described in this article was standardized by the recordings of the 1950s folk group Los Hermanos Abalos (Abalos 1952). Today, this style is ubiquitous throughout Argentina, with important variants appearing in the provinces of Santiago del Estero and Salta.
===Melody and harmony=== Contemporary Chacareras generally utilize descending, minor-mode melodies within an octave range. They are not harmonically distinctive, relying predominantly on tonic and dominant accompaniment, and the occasional shift to the relative major. Some modern Chacarera musicians use major-seventh and other altered chords in their arrangements.
===Rhythm=== Contemporary Chacarera music is distinguished by its unique [[hemiola]] [[syncopation]]. Melody lines tend to begin in duple meter ({{music|time|6|8}}), and conclude in triple meter ({{music|time|3|4}}). Accompaniment parts – including those on guitar, piano, bandoneón and drum – employ a constant compound meter of {{music|time|6|8}} and {{music|time|3|4}}, with accents on the second dotted quarter and the third quarter note, respectively (Abalos 1952). The downbeat is generally elided until cadences, a characteristic that is particularly salient in the case of the “Chacarera Trunca” style, which cadences on the third beat.
===Structure=== The Chacarera is a binary form. The A section (6 or 8 bars) doubles as an introduction and an interlude. The B section (8 bars) returns twice before concluding with a repetition. The entire form repeats two times. A B A B A B B
==Chacarera choreography== The Chacarera is a [[Contradance]]-influenced partner dance with similarities to many Ibero-American folk dances, including the Chilean (Zama) cueca and the Peruvian [[Marinera]] (Vega 1944). Male dancers circle about their female partners, seducing them with foot stomping ([[zapateo]]) and handkerchief waving during the A sections and “coronating,” or embracing, them in the final B section.
==History of the Chacarera genre== According to the musicologist Carlos Vega (Vega 1944), the Chacarera belongs to a family of Ibero-American dances derived from baroque Contradance choreography. While this assertion may be accurate, Vega himself admits to the absence of documentation regarding the Chacarera before the advent of the recording industry. As the first mention of the Chacarera as a musical genre appears in the early twentieth century publications of the [[Santiagueñan]] band leader Andrés Chazarreta, it may thus be more accurate to place this dance’s “origin” within the modern era.
===Argentine musical nationalism=== The Chacarera can be understood as an outgrowth of Argentine "[[Nativism (politics)|nativism]]," a nationalist "back-to-the-roots" movement inspired by increasing Argentine urbanization, and the influence of romantic European philosophy (Delaney 2002). The musical impact of “nativism” was felt particularly strongly in the rural province of Santiago del Estero, a region identified as a wellspring of “authentic” Argentine culture (Rojas 1905). Both Argentine individuals and institutions were inspired by the nativist perspective. In 1911, the Santiagueñan band leader Andrés Chazarreta established the nation’s first folk music “ballet” (Compañía de bailes nativos) (Vega 1981). In 1917, meanwhile, the Universidad de Tucumán hired the pianist Manuel Gómez Carrillo to conduct ethnomusicological research in Santiago (Veniard 1999). Chazarreta and Carrillo’s publications are the first to mention the Chacarera as a musical genre. While both musicians claimed to be replicating “folk” traditions in their books and recordings, some scholars credit them with establishing the form and choreography of the dance (Chazarreta 2007).
===Impact of the recording industry=== The Chacarera recordings and compositions of Manuel Gómez Carrillo and Andrés Chazarreta have provided a foundation for recording artists throughout the twentieth century, including Atahualpa Yupanqui, Los Hermanos Abalos, and more recent musical ensembles like the Dúo Coplanacu, Peteco Carabajal and La Chacarerata Santiagueña. The distribution of these recordings via record and radio has led to the establishment of local, national, and international audiences for the genre. In Santiago del Estero, Mendoza, and Buenos Aires alike, musicians gather in Peñas, or small folkloric clubs, to sing and dance their favorite Chacareras, often with specific regional flare. In neighboring nation-states including Uruguay, Perú, Brazil, Bolivia and Chile, Chacarera recordings of artists like Yupanqui are well-known, and often incorporated into local repertoires.
===Chacarera as art music=== The Chacarera has also provided inspiration for art music composers like Alberto Ginastera, who used the genre’s distinctive syncopations frequently in his work. Manuel Gómez Carrillo himself was a conservatory-trained pianist, and set a precedent for this kind of “academic” setting in his compositions for solo piano.
==Some famous chacareras== *Añoranzas (Julio Argentino Gerez)(this is a "chacarera doble) *Chacarera de las Piedras (Yupanqui) *La Olvidada (Yupanqui) *La Vieja (Hermanos Abalos) *Chacarera del rancho (Hermanos Abalos) *Chacarera Santiagueña (Los Tucu Tucu)

{{Infobox game | title = ''Çoan ki'' | image_link = [[File:Coanki.tiff|200px]] | image_caption = Thomas Hyde's illustration of the game ''Coan Ki'', from ''De Ludus Orientalibris'' (1694) | years = | genre = [[Board game]], [[dice game]], [[race game]] | players = 2 | setup_time = | playing_time = | random_chance = Medium | skills = }} '''''Çoan ki''''' ({{zh|t=樽棋|p=zunqi|w=tsun k'i}}, also ''erectus ludus'' or "The Bottle Game") is a Chinese [[board game]] similar to [[backgammon]].<ref name="Culin1991">{{cite book|author=Stewart Culin|title=Korean games: with notes on the corresponding games of China and Japan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mopZAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=18 March 2013|date=1 January 1991|publisher=Brooklyn Museum in association with Dover Publications|isbn=978-0-486-26593-3|page=81}}</ref> It was first described in 1694 by [[Thomas Hyde|Dr. Thomas Hyde]] in ''De Ludis Orientalibus Libri Duo''.<ref name="gamesmuseum">{{cite web | url=http://gamesmuseum.uwaterloo.ca/Archives/Culin/Dice1893/chongunchau.html | title=Elliott Avedon Virtual Museum Of Games | publisher=University of Waterloo | accessdate=June 21, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607183135/http://www.gamesmuseum.uwaterloo.ca/Archives/Culin/Dice1893/chongunchau.html | archivedate=June 7, 2011 | df= }}</ref><ref name="Bell1969">{{cite book|author=Robert Charles Bell|title=Board and table games from many civilizations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P-cTAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=18 March 2013|year=1969|publisher=Oxford U.P.|pages=12–13}}</ref>
==Gameplay== On a [[Game board|board]] divided transversely into eight fields, players take turns to move their sixteen bottle- or vase-shaped pieces around the board according to the roll of two [[dice]]. The aim of the game is to get all of a player's pieces to make one full circuit around the board and return them to their starting position.<ref name="Wykes1964">{{cite book|author=Alan Wykes|title=The complete illustrated guide to gambling|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q6m1AAAAIAAJ|accessdate=21 June 2012|year=1964|publisher=Doubleday|page=131}}</ref>
Dice rolls can be divided between pieces as follows: either one piece moves the total value of the throw, or two pieces move the values shown on each individual die. If a double is thrown, the player may move two pieces the total value of the throw or one piece half the value (such that if a double five is rolled, two pieces may each move ten spaces or one piece may move five spaces). If the two dice show consecutive numbers, the player may move one piece the full value of the throw and one piece the lower value, or he may move one piece the full value and another piece the full value minus one (e.g. a throw of two and three would allow either one piece to move two spaces and another five, or one piece to move five spaces and another four). A player must use the full roll of the dice; if he cannot do so, he loses his turn.
By stationing eight pieces in the same field of the board, a player can create a block, which cannot be passed by the other player. Blocks cannot be created on either of the starting fields.
Players must enter a [[ante (poker)|stake]] before the game begins. If at any time a player rolls double-one on the dice, he loses a piece and must stake an additional fine worth 10% of the total value of the pot. Under some [[wikt:rulebook|rule codes]], it is possible to avoid losing a piece by paying a larger fine. The winner of the game takes the [[Pot (poker)|pot]].<ref>{{cite book | title=The Book of Games | publisher=Sterling Publishing | author=Botermans, Jack | year=2008 | isbn=9781402742217}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

[[File:Smithson-Rolyat.jpg|thumb|Rolyat with [[Florence Smithson]] in ''[[The Arcadians (musical)|The Arcadians]]'' (1909)]] '''Dan Rolyat''', born '''Herbert Taylor''' (11 November 1872 – 10 December 1927), was an English actor and singer. After an apprenticeship with a touring company he was engaged by the impresarios [[George Edwardes]] and [[Robert Courtneidge]] to play comic roles in [[Edwardian musical comedy|musical comedy]]. He also played in [[variety show]]s and, later in his career, in [[farce]].
Rolyat's greatest success was probably in the double role of John Smith and Simplicitas in ''[[The Arcadians (musical)|The Arcadians]]'' (1909), first in the [[West End theatre|West End]] of London and then in the British provinces. While playing the role on tour he suffered a severe accident that threatened to end his career. He recovered and worked on until the mid-1920s when ill-health forced him to retire.
==Early life and career== Rolyat was born in [[Birmingham]] in the English midlands, the son of Thomas Taylor, described in ''Who's Who in the Theatre'' as a "private gentleman".<ref name=who>Parker, p. 790</ref> Rolyat was educated at [[Queen's College, Birmingham]].<ref name=who/>
He adopted the stage name of Dan Rolyat – "Dan" in honour of [[Dan Leno]] and "Rolyat" because he thought "Taylor" more distinctive when spelled backwards than forwards.<ref name=mg>"Mr Dan Rolyat", ''The Manchester Guardian'', 12 December 1927, p. 10</ref> He made his stage debut at Coutts's Theatre, Birmingham, in 1896, and joined a touring company playing in ''From Scotland Yard'' and ''Sentenced for Life''.<ref name=who/> He joined [[George Edwardes]]'s company, and toured as Sammy Gigg in the [[Edwardian musical comedy|musical comedy]] ''[[The Toreador]]'' (1901). He was a member of [[Fred Karno]]'s company, playing Sergeant Lightning in ''The Dandy Thieves'' (1905) and then appeared in [[variety show|variety]].<ref name=who/> He had established a reputation as a whimsically original comedian when he was cast for his first [[West End theatre|West End]] show in 1906<ref name=mg/> at the [[Apollo Theatre]].<ref name="DDT8">"Dan Rolyat: Tragedy of a great laughter-maker", ''Derby Daily Telegraph'', 10 December 1927, p. 8</ref> This was ''The Dairymaids'', by [[Paul Rubens (composer)|Paul Rubens]] and [[Arthur Wimperis]]. Rolyat played Joe Mivens; ''[[The Times]]'' thought him as funny as the show's star comedian, [[Walter Passmore]], and ''[[The Observer]]'' considered him to be the funnier of the two.<ref>"Apollo", ''The Times'', 16 April 1906, p. 10; and "''The Dairymaids'' at the Apollo", ''The Observer'', 15 April 1906, p. 7</ref> In 1907 Rolyat created the role of Benjamin Partridge in [[Edward German]]'s comic opera ''[[Tom Jones (Edward German)|Tom Jones]]''.<ref name=who/> That Christmas, he played the Baron in a [[pantomime]] version of ''[[Cinderella#Theatre|Cinderella]]'' at the [[Theatre Royal, Birmingham]].<ref name=who/>
''The Dairymaids'' had been produced by the impresario [[Robert Courtneidge]], who engaged Rolyat to create the double role of John Smith and Simplicitas in the long-running musical ''[[The Arcadians (musical)|The Arcadians]]'' in 1909.<ref name=who/> Also for Courtneidge, Rolyat played Suki in ''The Mousmé'' (1911).<ref name=who/> In 1912, while touring in ''The Arcadians,'' he fell from his horse in Act II and suffered such severe injuries to his back that there was some doubt whether he would ever be able to appear on stage again.<ref name=mg/> He recovered after several months and toured as Prince Bogumil in ''[[Princess Caprice]]'' in 1913.<ref name=who/>
==Later years== Returning to the West End in October 1914, Rolyat appeared as Simon Slinks in a revival of another musical, ''[[Miss Hook of Holland]]''. For the rest of his career he performed in variety and musical comedy, and in 1922 he played in a non-musical farce, ''Nuts in May''.<ref name=who/> In the mid-1920s his health gave way, and he had to retire from performing. He underwent surgery for [[oral cancer]], but the operation was unsuccessful.<ref name="DDT8"/> An all-star benefit show was organised to raise money to support him.<ref name=mg/>
Rolyat was twice married. His first wife was the singer and actress [[Florence Smithson]]; the marriage was dissolved, and in 1915 he married the actress Constance Worth.<ref name=who/> He died at his home in [[Brixton]], south London, at the age of fifty-five.<ref name=mg/>
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}

[[Jason Haigh-Ellery]] | production_code = | series = ''[[Bernice Summerfield]]'' | length = 1 episode, 9 mins. | date = {{Start date|2010|8|31|df=y}} | preceding = | following = }} '''''Dead and Buried''''' is an [[Animation|animated]] webcast based on the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' spin-off series ''[[Bernice Summerfield]]''. It was released free to watch on the official Big Finish YouTube channel on 31 August 2010. It's set between the stories ''[[Secret Origins (Bernice Summerfield)|Secret Origins]]'' and ''Resurrecting the Past''. ==Synopsis== Whilst Bernice waits for Irving Braxiatel's next actions, she goes to the planet Javarda to do some excavating on a site of ruins from an undiscovered civilization. But whilst there a bigger threat is waiting hidden for her to find. ==Cast== *[[Bernice Summerfield]] - [[Lisa Bowerman]] *[[Irving Braxiatel]] - [[Miles Richardson]] *Robot - John Ainsworth ==Broadcast== It was first released on the official [[Big Finish Productions]] YouTube channel to watch on 31 August 2010.[http://www.bigfinish.com/news/Bernice-Summerfield--Dead-and-Buried--Released! http://www.bigfinish.com/news/Bernice-Summerfield--Dead-and-Buried--Released!] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{YouTube|qwbWpBxosvo|''Bernice Summerfield: Dead and Buried''}} *{{TardisIndexFile|Dead and Buried}} {{Doctor Who}} [[Category:Bernice Summerfield]] [[Category:Webcasts based on Doctor Who]] [[Category:Animated web series]] [[Category:British web series]] {{DoctorWho-stub}}
