[[File:LHDLogo67.png|right|thumb|250px|Logo from the annual debate at the University of Chicago in 2013]] The '''Latke–Hamantash Debate''' is a deliberately humorous academic [[debate]] about the relative merits and meanings of these two items of [[Jewish cuisine]]. The debate originated at the [[University of Chicago]] in 1946<ref name=UCM>{{cite journal|title=Shticking to Their Puns|journal=University of Chicago Magazine|date=December 2005|volume=98|issue=2|url=http://magazine.uchicago.edu/0512/features/puns.shtml|accessdate=26 November 2014}}</ref> and has since been held annually. Subsequent debates have taken place at several other universities. Participants in the debate, held within the format of a [[symposium]], have included past University of Chicago president [[Hanna Holborn Gray]], [[philosopher]] [[Martha Nussbaum]], former [[Council of Economic Advisers]] Chairman [[Austan Goolsbee]], [[Nobel Prize]] winners [[Milton Friedman]], [[George Stigler]], [[Leon M. Lederman]], and [[essayist]] [[Allan Bloom]]. A compendium of the debate, which has never been won, was published in 2005.
==Background and history== {{multiple image |direction=vertical |width=220 |image1=Ukrainian potato pancakes.jpg |caption1=Latkes with sour cream |image2=Hamantaschen and milk.jpg |caption2=Hamantashen with milk }} A [[latke]] is a kind of [[potato]] pancake traditionally eaten during the Jewish holiday of [[Hanukkah]]. Fried in oil, latkes commemorate the holiday miracle in which one day’s worth of oil illuminated the temple for eight days. [[Hamantash]]en are triangular baked wheat-flour pastries with a sweet filling which are traditionally eaten on the holiday of [[Purim]]. They represent the ears or the 3-cornered hat of Haman, the villain of the Purim story in the Biblical [[book of Esther]].
A debate on their relative merits was first held in the winter of 1946 at the University of Chicago chapter house of the [[Hillel: The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life|Hillel Foundation]], sponsored by [[Rabbi]] Maurice Pekarsky.<ref name=LHD>{{cite book|editor1-last=Cernea|editor1-first=Ruth Fredman|title=The Great Latke-Hamantash Debate|date=2006|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago|isbn=0226100235|page=xix-xi|ref={{sfnRef|Cernea}}}}</ref> Participants in the debates have included [[Nobel Prize]] winners and [[MacArthur Genius Grant|MacArthur Grant Fellows]].<ref name=Okrent /> After the debate, both foodstuffs are usually served at a reception afterwards, offering debaters and listeners an opportunity to evaluate [[primary source]]s.<ref name=uc1/>
The debate had been moderated by University of Chicago philosophy professor Ted Cohen for over 25 years until his death in March 2014.<ref name=Cholke>{{cite web|last1=Cholke|first1=Sam|title=Latke or Hamantash? University of Chicago Profs Debate Superior Jewish Food|url=http://www.dnainfo.com/chicago/20130212/hyde-park/latke-or-hamantash-university-of-chicago-profs-debate-superior-jewish-food|website=DNAInfo|accessdate=26 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141219140247/http://www.dnainfo.com/chicago/20130212/hyde-park/latke-or-hamantash-university-of-chicago-profs-debate-superior-jewish-food|archivedate=19 December 2014|df=}}</ref><ref name="O'Donnell">{{cite news|last1=O'Donnell|first1=Maureen|title=Ted Cohen, University of Chicago philosophy professor who took humor seriously|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/26419996-418/ted-cohen-university-of-chicago-philosophy-professor-who-took-humor-seriously.html#.VHZczMluTtg|accessdate=26 November 2014|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=24 March 2014}}</ref> Several long-standing customs are observed at the University of Chicago: the debaters must have gained a Ph.D. or an equivalent advanced degree, arguments are encouraged to be made using the specific technical language of their discipline, participants must present themselves in [[academic regalia]], and the debaters must include at least one non-Jewish individual.{{sfn|Cernea|p=xxi}}
==Commentary== The events have attracted commentary from a number of individuals. [[Aaron David Miller]], who served as a peace negotiator between Israeli and Palestinian authorities, noted that the critical feature of the debate is that it is intractable, but that the event is "simply too important to abandon."<ref name=Rosenberg>{{cite web|last1=Rosenberg|first1=Yair|title=Judaism’s Epic Food Fight|url=http://tabletmag.com/jewish-news-and-politics/124811/judaisms-epic-food-fight|website=Tablet Magazine|accessdate=27 November 2014|date=21 February 2013}}</ref> Discussing the event's original purpose at the University of Chicago, Ruth Fredman Cernea observed that scholarly life discouraged exploration of Jewish traditions and did not facilitate ethnic relationships between students and faculty: "the event provided a rare opportunity for faculty to reveal their hidden Jewish souls and poke fun at the high seriousness of everyday academic life."<ref name=uc1>{{cite web|title=Shticking to Their Puns|url=http://magazine.uchicago.edu/0512/features/puns.shtml|publisher=[[University of Chicago]] Magazine|accessdate=2009-10-08}}</ref><ref name=Gluck>{{cite web|last1=Gluck|first1=Robert|title=Latke or Hamantash? The Debate Rages On|url=http://www.jns.org/latest-articles/2011/12/13/latke-or-hamantash-the-debate-rages-on.html#.VHatgcluTtg|website=JNS.org|publisher=Jewish and Israel News|accessdate=27 November 2014}}</ref> On a practical note, Cernea commented that examinations and term papers would cause stress in the student body and that the event served to help alleviate such tension toward the end of the fall.<ref name=Lerner>{{cite journal|last1=Lerner|first1=Saul|title=The Great Latke-Hamantash Debate (review)|journal=Shofar: An Interdisciplinary Journal of Jewish Studies|date=Winter 2007|volume=25|issue=2|pages=221–224|doi=10.1353/sho.2007.0036}}</ref> She also argued that the debates reflected broad ethnic changes in the United States when they were founded, and represented gradual integration.<ref name=Lerner />
==Notable debates and arguments== The debaters represent a range of academic disciplines. Some of the entries are described below: *Ted Cohen concluded an analysis of how correct philosophical reasoning would lead one to the latke by explaining, "A world without hamantashen would be a wretched world. A world without hamantashen might be unbearable. But a world without latkes is unthinkable."<ref name=UCP>{{cite web|last1=Cohen|first1=Ted|title=Excerpts from The Great Latke-Hamantash Debate|url=http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/100235.html|website=University of Chicago Press|accessdate=27 November 2014}}</ref> *[[Hanna Gray]] discussed the silence of [[Machiavelli]] on the subject; noting that "The silence of a wise man is always meaningful",<ref>Leo Strauss, Thoughts on Machiavelli (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1958), p. 35</ref> she comes to the conclusion that Machiavelli was Jewish, and like all wise people, for the latke.<ref name=UCM /> *[[Isaac Abella]], professor of physics, asserts that "Which is Better: the Latke or the Hamantash?" is an invalid question, since it does not exhibit the necessary property of universality, is culturally biased, implies gender specificity, exhibits geographical [[chauvinism]], and appeals to special interests.<ref name=UCM /> *[[Michael Silverstein]], professor in anthropology, linguistics, and psychology, argued that it is not mere coincidence that the English translation of the letters on the [[dreidl]] spells out [[Tums|T-U-M-S]]. He cites this as evidence that "God may play dice with the universe, but not with Mrs. Schmalowitz’s [[Kugel|lukshen kugl]], nor especially with her latkes and homntashen".<ref name=UCM /> *Professor [[Wendy Doniger]] of the divinity school, in a carefully footnoted paper entitled "The Archetypal Hamentasch: A Feminist Mythology", asserts that hamentaschen are a womb equivalent, and were worshiped in early [[matriarchal]] societies.{{sfn|Cernea|p=189}} *In the debate at [[MIT]], Robert J. Silbey, dean of its School of Science, cited Google, which returned 380,000 hits on a search for "latke" and only 62,000 for "hamantaschen". Silbey also claimed that latkes, not hamentashen, are the [[dark matter]] thought to make up over 21 percent of the mass of the universe. *[[Allan Bloom]] noted a possible conspiracy involving the [[Manischewitz]] company and the [[University of Chicago Business School]].<ref name=Okrent>{{cite news|last1=Okrent|first1=Arika|title=8 Great Arguments from the Latke-Hamentash Debate|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/31833/8-great-arguments-latke-hamentash-debate|accessdate=26 November 2014|work=[[Mental Floss]]|date=8 December 2012}}</ref> *An entry by economist [[Milton Friedman]] discussed "The Latke and the Hamantash at the Fifty-Yard Line".{{sfn|Cernea|p=71}} *Criminal lawyer and Professor [[Alan Dershowitz]], during a debate at Harvard University, accused the latke of increasing the United States' dependence on oil.<ref name=promise/> *[[Harvard]] University's 2007 debate featured{{explain|reason=That's great, but what did they say?|date=October 2015}} professors [[Steven Pinker]] and [[Alan Dershowitz]].<ref>[http://pinker.wjh.harvard.edu/lectures/index.html Steven Pinker's lecture website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070220043611/http://pinker.wjh.harvard.edu/lectures/index.html |date=2007-02-20 }}</ref> *In the fifth debate at [[Johns Hopkins University]] in December 2010, professors Jonathan Flombaum and [[Hollis Robbins]] made a case for the latke on semiotic and philosophical grounds, drawing upon [[Spinoza]] and [[Jacques Derrida]] to emphasize the latke’s ''[[différance]]'' and to argue that its joyous heterogeneity made it the better holiday food.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Robbins|first1=Hollis|title=Latke Hamantaschen Debate|url=http://www.slideshare.net/hrobbins01/latke-hamentaschen-debate}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.hopkins-interactive.com/buffet/2011/01/december-at-hopkins-4/ |title=December at Hopkins |website=Blue Jay Buffet |accessdate=15 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141219124335/http://blogs.hopkins-interactive.com/buffet/2011/01/december-at-hopkins-4/ |archivedate=19 December 2014 |df= }}]</ref> *In the 2011 debate at [[MIT]], particle physicist Allan Adams presented preliminary data from the [[LHC]]—the Latke Hamantash Collider—allegedly providing evidence for Latke Theory.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Latke vs Hamentaschen: The Great Debate 2011 {{!}} MIT Hillel|url = http://hillel.mit.edu/content/latke-vs-hamentaschen-great-debate-2011|website = hillel.mit.edu|accessdate = 2015-09-19}}</ref>{{Citation needed|date=December 2014}} *When he was President of Princeton University, [[Harold Tafler Shapiro]] argued the hamentaschen's superiority by pointing out the epicurean significance of the "edible triangle" in light of the literary "Oedipal triangle."{{Citation needed|date=December 2014}} *In a memorable debate in the early 1970s at the [[Clanton Park, Toronto|Clanton Park]] Synagogue Purim Party in Toronto, Canada, attorneys Aaron Weinstock and Meyer Feldman - debating in their formal legal robes and wigs - debated with much hilarity. The result was a draw.{{Citation needed|date=December 2014}} *In debates concerning law, participants have quoted from the majority opinion of [[Justice Blackmun]] in the case ''[[County of Allegheny v. ACLU]]'', which said: "It is also a custom to serve potato pancakes or other fried foods on Chanukah because the oil in which they are fried is, by tradition, a reminder of the miracle of Chanukah."<ref name=Blackmun>{{cite web|last1=Blackmun|first1=Harry|title=County of Allegheny v. ACLU 492 U.S. 573 (1989): Case|url=https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/492/573/case.html#F25|website=Justia US Supreme Court|publisher=[[Justia]]|accessdate=27 November 2014}}</ref><ref name=Wilgoren>{{cite news|last1=Wilgoren|first1=Jodi|title=Such Sound and Fury! Tradition! Einsteins in Food Fight of Words|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/25/national/25latke.html?ei=5088&en=081542c3f6d382f4&ex=1290574800&adxnnl=0&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss&adxnnlx=1132897253-d/nWiQSNoeF0GP433txSug&pagewanted=print|accessdate=27 November 2014|work=[[New York Times]]|date=25 November 2005}}</ref> The Supreme Court has given no such recognition to the hamantash. *The 2014 [[University of Chicago]] debate featured Chemistry professor Aaron Dinner, who argued from a standpoint of energy efficiency, that the latke is eight times more fuel efficient than the hamantash.<ref name=JUF>{{cite web|last1=Dekhtyar|first1=Sonya|last2=Solomon|first2=Lee|last3=Libenson|first3=Dajniel|title=Age-Old Debate Confounds Experts Again at U of C Hillel’s Latke-Hamantash Debate|url=http://www.juf.org/college/blog.aspx?id=66232&blogid=4866|website=[[Jewish United Fund]]|accessdate=27 November 2014}}</ref><ref name=Abowd>{{cite news|last1=Abowd|first1=Mary|title=68th Latke-Hamantash Debate set for Nov. 25|url=https://news.uchicago.edu/article/2014/11/14/68th-latke-hamantash-debate-set-nov-25|accessdate=27 November 2014|work=UChicago News|publisher=University of Chicago|date=14 November 2014}}</ref> * [[Yiddish language|Yiddishist]] and professor of [[computer science]] [[Raphael Finkel]] has pointed out that in the rabbinic literature there are extensive hallachic discussions concerning latkes but almost no mention of hamantashen.<ref>http://www.cs.uky.edu/~raphael/yiddish/homent.html</ref> *Because of the proximity to [[Passover]] of the date of the 2012 debate at [[St. Mary's College of Maryland]], Professor Josh Grossman initially adopted a third side in the debate: [[matzo]]. Upon further consideration, he promptly conceded.<ref name=SMCM>{{cite web|title=Adler and Rabinowitz Fight Viciously over Latke, Hamantaschen|url=http://thepointnews.com/2012/04/adler-and-rabinowitz-fight-viciously-over-latke-hamantaschen|accessdate=2012-04-03}}</ref>
==Debates at other institutions== Latke–Hamantash Debates have been held at several other universities and institutions including: *[[University of Denver]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Tonight at the Buntport: The Great Hamantasch/Latke Debate is Back!|url=https://www.westword.com/arts/free-and-cheap-things-to-do-in-denver-october-18-to-21-2018-10908524}}</ref> *[[Brandeis University]]<ref>{{cite web|title=latkes vs. hamantaschen settled|url=http://thebrandeishoot.com/articles/79}}</ref> *[[University of Wisconsin]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Laud the latke! Hurrah for the hamantasch!|url=https://isthmus.com/isthmus-giving-magazine/laud-the-latke-hurrah-for-the-hamantasch/}}</ref> *[[University of Michigan]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=Akhtar|first1=Allana|title=Professors engage in spirited debate on Jewish foods|url=https://www.michigandaily.com/news/hillel-debate|accessdate=22 October 2015|work=[[Michigan Daily]]|date=19 November 2013}}</ref> *[[Harvard University]]<ref name=promise>{{cite web|title=Latkes vs. Hamantashen: The Promised Food|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=517444|accessdate=2008-05-23}}</ref> *[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Profs Face Off on Latkes Versus Hamantaschen|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V126/N9/9latke.html|accessdate=2008-05-23}}</ref> *[[Princeton University]] *[[Williams College]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Proof of the Superiority of Hamentashen over Latkes|url=http://philosophy.williams.edu/articles/proof-of-the-superiority-of-hamentashen-over-latkes/}}</ref> *[[University of Minnesota]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Prattle of the ages: Hamantasch vs. latke|url=https://www.mndaily.com/articles/2006/02/27/67353|archive-url=https://archive.is/20080115162957/http://www.mndaily.com/articles/2006/02/27/67353|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2008-01-15|accessdate=2008-05-23}}</ref> *[[Mount Holyoke College|Mount Holyoke]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Latke-Hamantasch Debate Becomes Verbal Food Fight|url=http://www.mtholyoke.edu/offices/comm/csj/970404/food.html|accessdate=2008-05-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060430064239/http://www.mtholyoke.edu/offices/comm/csj/970404/food.html|archivedate=2006-04-30|df=}}</ref> *[[Graduate Theological Union]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Latke-hamantaschen debate in Berkeley ends with a stunning verdict|url=http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/71158/latke-hamantaschen-debate-in-berkeley-ends-with-a-stunning-verdict/}}</ref> *[[Bowdoin College]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Professors debate merits of latkes, hamantash|url=http://orient.bowdoin.edu/orient/article.php?date=2009-02-27&section=1&id=4|accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref> *[[University of Connecticut]]<ref>{{cite web|title=The First Annual UConn Latkes vs Hamentashen Debate|url=http://judaicstudies.uconn.edu/2015/04/07/the-first-annual-uconn-latkes-vs-hamentashen-debate/|accessdate=2015-12-07}}</ref> *[[Swarthmore College]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.swarthmore.edu/student-life/latke-hamantaschen-debate|title=Latke-Hamantaschen Debate :: Student Life :: Swarthmore College|website=www.swarthmore.edu|access-date=2016-03-29}}</ref> *[http://www.jcckrakow.org/en/ Jewish Community Center (JCC) - Krakow, Poland]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jewishfestival.pl/en/the-sixth-annual-debate-latkes-vs-hamantaschen/|title=JCC Krakow Latke-Hamantash Debate|last=Lorch|first=Benjamin|date=25 June 2017|website=|accessdate=25 June 2017}}</ref> *[[University of South Florida]] - A USF Hillel Program
==Footnotes== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www-news.uchicago.edu/releases/95/951110.latke.hamentash.shtml History of the debate ] *[[Eric Zorn]], columnist for the [[Chicago Tribune]], addresses the [http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/technology_internetcritic/2005/11/whole_lotta_lat.html debate] **[http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/100235.html Text and audio of Ted Cohen's 1976 debate speech, "Consolations of the Latke"]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company |name = Maximum Fighting Championship |logo = [[File:Maximum fighting championship logo.jpg]] |type = Private |foundation = 2001-2014 |founder = Mark Pavelich |industry = [[Mixed martial arts]] promotion |parent = Pavelich Sports Inc. |sibling = |slogan = |homepage = http://www.maximumfighting.com |location_city = [[Edmonton, Alberta]] |location_country= Canada |key_people = Mark Pavelich (CEO)
Dave Pavelich (Vice-President)
Manon Pavelich (Treasurer/Tickets)http://www.maximumfighting.com/history.htm{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} }} '''Maximum Fighting Championship''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]] [[mixed martial arts]] (MMA) promotion based in [[Edmonton, Alberta]]. MFC’s former home, in Canada, is the River Cree Resort and Casino in Enoch, Alberta, located just outside Edmonton, Alberta but has also held events at the [[Edmonton Expo Centre]].{{cite web|url=http://mmamania.com/2010/5/8/1463318/mfc-25-results-recap-and-post|title=MFC 25 results, recap and post-fight discussion for 'Vindication' on May 7|author=James Iannotti|work=MMAmania.com|accessdate=6 June 2015}} MFC events are broadcast on [[The Fight Network]], [[AXS TV]] (formerly HDnet) in [[North America]] and most recently [[TSN2]]. MFC is known to be the biggest MMA promotion in Canada and one of the top MMA shows in the World. MFC has notable Canadian fighters, such as [[Ryan Jimmo]], Graham Spencer, [[Tom Watson (fighter)|Tom Watson]] and [[Douglas Lima]], plus MMA veterans, such as [[Jason MacDonald]], [[Thales Leites]], [[Jay Silva]], [[Trevor Prangley]], and [[Paul Daley]].http://www.maximumfighting.com/mfcorg.htm{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==History== Maximum Fighting Championship was founded on March 3, 2001, by Pavelich Sports Inc. Mark Pavelich is the CEO of MFC and runs the business day to day. Dave Pavelich is Vice President and Manon Pavelich is the booker. MFC currently airs on [[AXS TV Fights]] in the U.S. and [[The Fight Network]] in Canada. MFC’s former home was the ''River Cree Resort and Casino'' in Enoch, Alberta, Canada located just outside Edmonton, Alberta. Their new home is the ''Mayfield Inn Trade and Conference Centre'' Edmonton, Alberta. In July 2011, MFC signed a five-year live TV deal with [[HDnet]] (now [[AXS TV]]) and in October 2011, MFC signed with [[TSN2]]. MFC hosts heavyweight fights but doesn't have a heavyweight championship due to the lack of heavyweights outside of the top promotions. MFC employs the Unified Rules of Mixed Martial Arts. All MFC bouts take place in a [[Boxing ring|ring]], with the exception of MFC 29 which, in accordance with the regulations utilized in Ontario which requires all mixed martial arts fights to be held in a cage structure, took place in a circular cage named "''The Ring''" by the winner of a "''Name the Cage''" fan contest.{{cite web|url=http://www.maximumfighting.com/news/mfc-stays-in-the-ring/|title=MFC stays in THE RING|publisher=maximumfighting.com|date=2011-04-11|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225100900/http://www.maximumfighting.com/news/mfc-stays-in-the-ring/|archivedate=2013-12-25|df=}} In 2012, MFC announced the re-launched its heavyweight division and the upcoming debut of a featherweight division. In 2013, the Maximum Fighting Championship also announced that the organization would add a bantamweight with the debut bout taking place on May 19, 2013 at MFC 37: True Grit. MFC has not held an event since MFC 41 'All In" on October 3, 2014. Mark Pavelich announced that Maximum Fighting Championship was up for sale on February 18, 2016. {{cite web|url=http://www.mmaweekly.com/maximum-fighting-championship-is-for-sale|title=Maximum Fighting Championship is For Sale - MMAWeekly.com|author=|date=|website=www.mmaweekly.com|accessdate=23 April 2018}} ==Rules== MFC employs the [[Unified Rules of Mixed Martial Arts]]. ===Rounds=== Every round in MFC competition is five minutes in duration. Title matches have five such rounds, and non-title matches have three. There is a one-minute rest period between rounds.http://www.maximumfighting.com/rules.htm{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===Weight divisions=== {{See also|Mixed martial arts weight classes}} MFC currently uses six weight classes: {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:95%; text-align:center;" !rowspan="2"|Weight class name !colspan="2"|Upper limit |- !in [[Pound (mass)|pounds]] (lb) !in [[kilogram]]s (kg) |- |align="left"|[[Bantamweight (MMA)|Bantamweight]] |135||61 |- |align="left"|[[Lightweight (MMA)|Featherweight]] |145||66 |- |align="left"|[[Lightweight (MMA)|Lightweight]] |155||70 |- |align="left"|[[Welterweight (MMA)|Welterweight]] |170||77 |- |align="left"|[[Middleweight (MMA)|Middleweight]] |185||84 |- |align="left"|[[Light Heavyweight (MMA)|Light Heavyweight]] |205||93 |- |align="left"|[[Heavyweight (MMA)|Heavyweight]] |265||120 |- |[[Super heavyweight (MMA)|Super Heavyweight]] | colspan=2|No weight limit |- |} ===Attire=== All competitors must fight in approved shorts, without shoes. Shirts, [[Keikogi|gis]] or long pants (including gi pants) are not allowed. Fighters must use approved light-weight open-fingered gloves, that include at least 1" of padding around the knuckles, (110 to 170 g / 4 to 6 ounces) that allow fingers to grab. These gloves enable fighters to punch with less risk of an injured or broken hand, while retaining the ability to grab and grapple. ===Match outcome=== Matches usually end via: *'''[[Submission (combat sport term)|Submission]]''': a fighter clearly taps on the mat or his opponent or verbally submits. *'''Technical Submission''': A technical submission is achieved when the referee stops a fight due to an injury resulting from a submission hold or due to a fighter going unconscious from a choke. *'''[[Knockout]]''': a fighter falls from a legal blow and is either unconscious or unable to immediately continue. *'''Technical Knockout''' (TKO): If a fighter cannot continue, the fight is ended as a technical knockout. Technical knockouts can be classified into three categories: **referee stoppage: (the referee determines a fighter cannot "intelligently defend" himself; if warnings to the fighter to improve his position or defense go unanswered—generally, two warnings are given, about 5 seconds apart) **doctor stoppage (a ringside doctor due to injury or impending injury, as when blood flows into the eyes and blinds a fighter) **corner stoppage (a fighter's own corner-man signals defeat for their own fighter) *'''Judges' Decision''': Depending on scoring, a match may end as: **unanimous decision (all three judges score a win for fighter A) **majority decision (two judges score a win for fighter A, one judge scores a draw) **split decision (two judges score a win for fighter A, one judge scores a win for fighter B) **unanimous draw (all three judges score a draw) **majority draw (two judges score a draw, one judge scoring a win) **split draw (one judge scores a win for fighter A, one judge scores a win for fighter B, and one judge scores a draw) Note: In the event of a draw, it is not necessary that the fighters' total ''points'' be equal. However, in a unanimous or split draw, each fighter does score an equal number of ''win judgments'' from the three judges (0 or 1, respectively). A fight can also end in a '''technical decision''', '''disqualification''', '''forfeit''', '''technical draw''', or '''no contest'''. The latter two outcomes have no winners. ===Judging criteria=== The [[10-point must system|ten-point must system]] is in effect for all fights; three judges score each round and the winner of each receives ten points, the loser nine points or fewer. If the round is even, both fighters receive ten points. ===Fouls=== The Nevada State Athletic Commission currently lists the following as fouls:[http://www.leg.state.nv.us/NAC/NAC-467.html NSAC Regulations: Chapter 467 - Unarmed Combat]. Nevada State Athletic Commission. Retrieved April 3, 2006 #[[headbutt|Butting]] with the head #[[eye-gouging|Eye gouging]] of any kind #Biting #Hair pulling #[[fish-hooking|Fish hooking]] #[[Groin attack]]s of any kind #Putting a finger into any orifice or into any cut or laceration on an opponent. (see [[Gouging (fighting style)|Gouging]]) #[[Small joint manipulation]] #Striking to the spine or the back of the head (see [[Rabbit punch]]) #Striking downward using the point of the elbow (see [[Elbow (strike)]]) #[[Throat]] strikes of any kind, including, without limitation, grabbing the [[Vertebrate trachea|trachea]] #Clawing, pinching or twisting the flesh #Grabbing the [[clavicle]] #[[soccer kick|Kicking]] the head of a grounded opponent #[[knee (strike)|Kneeing]] the head of a grounded opponent #[[stomp (strike)|Stomping]] a grounded opponent #[[Kick]]ing to the kidney with the heel #Spiking an opponent to the canvas on his head or neck. (see [[piledriver (professional wrestling)|piledriver]]) #[[throw (grappling)|Throwing]] an opponent out of the ring or fenced area #Holding the shorts or gloves of an opponent #Spitting at an opponent #Engaging in unsportsmanlike conduct that causes an injury to an opponent #Holding the ropes or the fence #Using abusive language in the ring or fenced area #Attacking an opponent on or during the break #Attacking an opponent who is under the care of the referee #Attacking an opponent after the bell (horn) has sounded the end of a round #Flagrantly disregarding the instructions of the referee #Timidity, including, without limitation, avoiding contact with an opponent, intentionally or consistently dropping the mouthpiece or faking an injury #Interference by the corner #Throwing in the towel during competition When a foul is charged, the referee in their discretion may deduct one or more points as a penalty. If a foul incapacitates a fighter, then the match may end in a disqualification if the foul was intentional, or a no contest if unintentional. If a foul causes a fighter to be unable to continue later in the bout, it ends with a technical decision win to the injured fighter if the injured fighter is ahead on points, otherwise it is a technical draw. ===Match conduct=== * After a verbal warning the referee can stop the fighters and stand them up if they reach a stalemate on the ground (where neither are in a dominant [[Grappling position|position]] or working towards one). * If the referee pauses the match, it is resumed with the fighters in their prior positions. * Grabbing the ring ropes brings a verbal warning, followed by an attempt by the referee to release the grab by pulling on the grabbing hand. If that attempt fails or if the fighter continues to hold the ropes, the referee may charge a foul. ===Title fights=== On September 18, 2012 MFC instituted new regulations regarding title fights.{{cite web|url=http://www.mmamania.com/2012/9/18/3354394/maximum-fighting-championship-mfc-weigh-in-drug-testing|title=Maximum Fighting Championship (MFC) institutes new regulations for title fights, weigh-ins and drug testing|publisher=MMAmania.com|date=2012-09-18}} '''Title Fight with a reigning/defending champion''' *If the champion fails to make weight: **SCENARIO 1 - The champion vacates the title immediately. The fight remains a five-round contest. If the vacated champion wins the fight, the Maximum Fighting Championship holds the option to automatically consider him the No. 1 contender for the next title fight in that weight class. The Maximum Fighting Championship also holds an option to make an immediate rematch. **SCENARIO 2 - The champion vacates the title immediately. The fight remains a five-round contest. If the challenger wins the fight, the challenger becomes the MFC champion. The Maximum Fighting Championship holds an option to make an immediate rematch. *If the challenger fails to make weight: **The champion automatically retains the belt. A non-title fight takes place and the Maximum Fighting Championship solely determines if the bout is a three- or five-round fight. If the challenger wins the bout, the Maximum Fighting Championship holds an option to make a future rematch. *If both fighters fail to make weight: **The champion vacates the title immediately. A non-title fight takes place and the Maximum Fighting Championship solely determines if the bout is a three- or five-round fight. The Maximum Fighting Championship holds the option to consider the winner of the bout as the No. 1 contender for the next title fight in that weight class. The Maximum Fighting Championship also holds an option to make future rematch. '''Title Fight with a vacant championship''' *If one fighter fails to make weight: **The fight remains a five-round contest. If the fighter who made weight wins the bout, he becomes the MFC champion of that weight class. If the fighter who failed to make weight wins the bout, that fighter does not claim the title, and the Maximum Fighting Championship holds the option to make him the No. 1 contender and/or to make an immediate rematch. *If both fighters fail to make weight: **A non-title bout takes place and the Maximum Fighting Championship solely determines if the bout is a three- or five-round fight. The Maximum Fighting Championship holds the option to make a future rematch. ==Events== {{Main article|List of MFC events}} As of October 3, 2014, the Maximum Fighting Championship has held a total of '''44''' events, all of which have taken place in [[Alberta]], Canada with the exception of MFC 29 which took place in [[Windsor, Ontario]], Canada. ==Current champions== {| style="border-collapse: collapse;" border="1" cellpadding="3" |- bgcolor="#FFFFCC" ! Division ! Upper weight limit ! Champion ! Since ! Title Defenses ! Next fight |- | [[Heavyweight (MMA)|Heavyweight]] | {{convert|265|lb|kg st|abbr=on}} | {{font color|gray|Vacant}} | | | |- | [[Light Heavyweight (MMA)|Light Heavyweight]] | {{convert|205|lb|kg st|abbr=on}} | {{font color|gray|Vacant}} | | | |- | [[Middleweight (MMA)|Middleweight]] | {{convert|185|lb|kg st|abbr=on}} | {{font color|gray|Vacant}} | | | |- | [[Welterweight (MMA)|Welterweight]] | {{convert|170|lb|kg st|abbr=on}} | {{font color|gray|Vacant}} | | | |- | [[Lightweight (MMA)|Lightweight]] | {{convert|155|lb|kg st|abbr=on}} | {{flagicon|USA}} Tom Gallicchio | May 9, 2014 | align=center| 0 | |- | [[Featherweight (MMA)|Featherweight]] | {{convert|145|lb|kg st|abbr=on}} | {{font color|gray|Vacant}} | | | |- | [[Bantamweight (MMA)|Bantamweight]] | {{convert|135|lb|kg st|abbr=on}} | {{font color|gray|Vacant}} | | | |- |} ==Title history== ===Heavyweight Championship=== :''206-265 lbs (93 - 120 kg)'' {| class="wikitable" width=100% !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=1%|No. !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=20%|Name !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=19%|Event !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=17%|Date !style="background: #e3e3e3;" width=44%|Defenses |- !1 |{{flagicon|USA}} '''[[Anthony Hamilton (fighter)|Anthony Hamilton]]'''

{{Infobox organization | name = Miss Exotic World Pageant | logo = MissExoticWorld2006JulieAtlasMuz.jpg | logo_size = | caption = [[Burlesque]] performer [[Julie Atlas Muz]] immediately after accepting the trophy as the 2006 Miss Exotic World [[beauty pageant|pageant]] winner | motto = | type = [[Burlesque]] [[beauty pageant|pageant]] | headquarters = [[Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]], US | location = Las Vegas, Nevada, [[United States]] | formation = 1990 | language = [[English language|English]] | key_people = [[Dixie Evans]] (founder){{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/11/arts/dance/dixie-evans-who-brought-monroe-to-burlesque-houses-dies-at-86.html?_r=0 |title=Dixie Evans, Who Brought ‘Monroe’ to Burlesque Houses, Dies at 86 |first= Margalit |last=Fox |authorlink=Margalit Fox |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=10 August 2013 |page=A21}} {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/10226445/Dixie-Evans.html|title=Dixie Evans Obituary|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]}} | affiliations = | parent_organization =
[[Burlesque Hall of Fame]] | budget = | website = {{URL|www.exoticworldusa.org/}} }} [[File:MichelleLAmourFanDance2555.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Fan dance by Miss Exotic World 2005 [[Michelle L'amour]] at the 2007 Miss Exotic World Pageant]] The '''Miss Exotic World Pageant''' (officially, the Miss Exotic World Pageant and Striptease Reunion) is an annual [[neo-burlesque]] pageant and convention, and is the annual showcase event (and fundraiser for) the [[Burlesque Hall of Fame]] (formerly the Exotic World burlesque museum). The pageant, sometimes referred to as the "Miss America of Burlesque", attracts former [[American burlesque|burlesque]] queens from past decades, as well as current participants of the neo-burlesque scene. The pageant consists of burlesque performances spanning a weekend, culminating with the competition to crown a single performer as Miss Exotic World. Because of the significance of the Exotic World Burlesque Museum to the burlesque community, winning the pageant is considered a top honor for a burlesque performer.{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/news/miss-exotic-world-dixies-chicks-2136597|title=Miss Exotic World: Dixie's Chicks |first=Paul|last=Cullum|date=19 June 2003|publisher=|accessdate=22 April 2018|via=www.laweekly.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.papermag.com/viva-la-nipple-a-report-from-the-2008-miss-exotic-world-pageant-of-bur-1425440906.html|title=Viva La Nipple! A Report from the 2008 Miss Exotic World Pageant of Burlesque|first=Melissa|last=Seley|date=27 June 2008|publisher=|accessdate=22 April 2018|via=www.papermag.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.burlexe.com/burlesque/twenty-five-years-of-miss-exotic-world-winners/|title=25 years of Miss Exotic World Winners|first=Serena|last=Doherty|date=7 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=22 April 2018|via=www.laweekly.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-crown-jewels-of-burlesque/|title=The Crown Jewels of Burlesque|date=13 June 2003|publisher=|accessdate=22 April 2018|via=cbsnews.com}} == History == === 1990 to 2004 === The pageant grew out an annual event held by [[Jennie Lee (dancer)]] and the Exotic Dancers' League (EDL), first held in 1958 and then annually through 1989. Awards were given out starting in 1962 to performers and promoters who furthered burlesque and showed it in a positive light. After Lee's death in 1990, the pageant was created and took place at the Exotic World Museum's grounds in [[Helendale, California]] from 1991 through 2005 before relocating to [[Las Vegas]]. Exotic World Museum curator [[Dixie Evans]] initiated the Miss Exotic World pageant in 1990 as a way to draw people to the museum.{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/dixie-evans-late-burlesque-pioneer-celebrated-community-helped-shape-article-1.1443566|title=Dixie Evans, late burlesque pioneer, celebrated at Vegas striptease show: ‘She was so fun, heartwarming, inspiring’ |date=2 Sep 2013|publisher=|accessdate=22 April 2018|via=nydailynews.com}}{{cite news|url=https://www.sbsun.com/2013/09/01/dixie-evans-godmother-of-burlesque-honored-at-las-vegas-tribute-show/|title=Dixie Evans, godmother of burlesque, honored at Las Vegas tribute show|newspaper=[[The San Bernardino Sun]]|date=1 Sep 2013|publisher=|accessdate=22 April 2018|}} She garnered attention by sending out a press release claiming that "[[Lili St. Cyr]], [[Tempest Storm]], [[Blaze Starr]] and 30 other alumni of burlesque will all be invited to attend this reunion." While technically true, none of those invitees attended that year. However, the release garnered press attention for the pageant, which was successful enough to become an annual event, held on the first Saturday in June each year, close to the traditional time of year of the EDL's previous annual events.{{cite web|url=http://21stcenturyburlesque.com/history-miss-exotic-world-pageant-jo-weldon-burlesque-hall-of-fame-judging-dixie-evans-jennie-lee/|title=A Brief History of the Miss Exotic World Pageant|first=Jo|last=Weldon|date=8 July 2014|publisher=|accessdate=22 April 2018|via=21stcenturyburlesque.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.burlesquehall.com/tag/miss-exotic-world/|title=Miss Exotic World tagged posts|accessdate=22 April 2018|via=burlesquehall.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/behold/2013/10/25/stephanie_diani_dames_the_legends_of_burlesque_focuses_on_the_legendary.html|title=Glamorous Burlesque Dancers of a Certain Age|accessdate=25 Oct 2013|via=slate.com}} === 2005 === In 2005, the pageant significantly expanded to mark its 15th year, as well as to accelerate [[Exotic World Burlesque Museum|the museum]]'s fundraising efforts. Where originally the pageant had been a one-day event, it grew and was expanded to last a weekend after its first decade. The new format featured an entire evening dedicated to the "legends" – the mostly sexuagenarian and septuagenarian women of burlesque's "golden age" of the 1950s and 1960s. Other new changes to the pageant included the expansion of financial sponsors; a glossy souvenir program; a celebrity master of ceremonies ([[El Vez]]); expanded seating (and shade areas); and a professional entertainment stage with sound and lighting as an improvement upon the aging wooden stage that had been used in previous years. Some of the most significant changes by 2005 were changes to the pageant application and judging process; changes that had been initiated in 2001. The pageant had expanded from having only one "Miss Exotic World" category to now include other new categories such as Best Debut. Additionally, the application process was tightened up, with the evaluation method standardized to further ensure professionalism and fairness.{{cite web|url=http://www.peepshowmenagerie.com/nofimagazine/50exoticw1.htm|title=No-Fi Magazine visits Miss Exotic World Pageant 2005|first=Chris|last=Beyond|accessdate=22 April 2018|via=www.peepshowmenagerie.com}} === 2006 to present === In 2006, the pageant took place in a new location, [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], in the wake of certain events that greatly affected the museum's operational ability. (Specifically, the state of disrepair of the property, and the death of property owner Charles Arroyo.) With the museum's impending move to Las Vegas, the pageant was held there, based at the Celebrity Theater in downtown Las Vegas. The pageant, up to that point held on the first Saturday in June, was instead held over Memorial Day weekend in late May, 2006. The pageant consisted of four evenings' worth of events and featured dual hosts [[Margaret Cho]] and [[El Vez]]. Since 2006, the pageant has made Las Vegas its permanent home.{{cite web|url=http://www.westword.com/arts/denvers-midnite-martini-wins-burlesques-miss-exotic-world-title-in-las-vegas-5784583|title=Denver's Midnite Martini wins burlesque's Miss Exotic World title in Las Vegas |first=Amber|last=Taufen|date=17 June 2014|publisher=|accessdate=22 April 2018|via=www.westword.com}}{{cite web|url=https://lasvegasweekly.com/blogs/the-playground/2009/jun/08/taking-it-many-queens-miss-exotic-world-2009/#/0 |title=Taking it off with the many queens of Miss Exotic World 2009 |first=Jennifer|last=Grafiada|date=8 June 2009|publisher=|accessdate=22 April 2018|via=lasvegasweekly.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/entertainment/entertainment-columns/kats/burlesque-show-ends-with-a-bang-a-shake-and-whos-on-first/|title=Burlesque show ends with a bang, a shake and ‘Who’s on first’|first=John|last=Katsilometes|date=4 June 2017|publisher=|accessdate=22 April 2018|via=www.reviewjournal.com}} ==Miss Exotic World winners== {{Main article|List of Miss Exotic World Pageant participants and winners}} == See also == *[[Nudes-A-Poppin']] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{Commonscat-inline}} *[http://www.behindtheburlyq.com ''Behind the Burly Q'']. 2010 documentary film by Leslie Zemeckis *[http://exoticworldthemovie.com ''Exotic World & the Burlesque Revival'']. 2010 documentary film by Red Tremmel {{Burlesque Hall of Fame}} [[Category:Burlesque]] [[Category:Beauty pageants in the United States|Exotic]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1990]] [[Category:1990 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:American awards]]

{{Infobox person | name = Paul Kieve | image = | birth_place = [[Woodford, London|Woodford]], [[London]] | occupation = Illusionist, magic effects creator }}
'''Paul Kieve''' (born 1967) is an [[English people|English]] professional [[Magic (illusion)|illusionist]] and whose consulting work for both stage and screen has contributed to changing how magical [[special effects]] in productions are approached. He is the only illusionist ever to have won a New York Drama Desk award (for ''[[Ghost the Musical]]'' on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]). He created the illusions for the 2014 [[Kate Bush]] concert ''[[Before the Dawn (Kate Bush)|Before the Dawn]]''.
==Early life== Kieve was born in [[Woodford, London|Woodford]], North-East [[London]]<ref name="M E N">{{cite web |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/entertainment/music/classical_and_opera/s/154/154273_kieve_reveals_secrets_of_the_spells.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130421073823/http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/entertainment/music/classical_and_opera/s/154/154273_kieve_reveals_secrets_of_the_spells.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 April 2013 |title=Kieve reveals secrets of the spells |last=Rooth |first=Ben |date=11 April 2005 |work=Manchester Evening News |accessdate=4 January 2010}}</ref> and started magic at 10 years of age after receiving a magic set as a [[birthday]] gift.
==Early performing career== Kieve first performed publicly in 1983. In January 1984 at the age of 16 he performed card tricks in the music video for the [[Sade (band)|Sade]] single [[Your Love Is King]], his arms having been shaved to give the impression that the singer was performing the [[prestidigitation]] herself.<ref name="Rees">{{Cite news|title=Paul Kieve: The real-life Jonathan Creek|last=Rees|first=Jasper|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=14 June 2011 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-features/8575717/Paul-Kieve-The-real-life-Jonathan-Creek.html}}</ref>
In April of that year he made his first television appearance on the BBC TV children's show ''[[Blue Peter]]'', apparently cutting presenter [[Janet Ellis]] into three pieces .
In 1985 he was a finalist in the "Young [[Magician (illusion)|Magician]] of the Year" competition.
Early professional engagements as a performer included a 1985 residency at the Xenon nightclub on [[Piccadilly]], [[London]] and a summer 1986 run at the Inn on The Park, [[Jersey]] where he was resident support to acts including [[Bernard Manning]], [[Gloria Gaynor]], [[Bob Monkhouse]], [[Rolf Harris]] and [[Ken Dodd]].
In 1986 he and Lawrence Leyton formed The Zodiac Brothers and performed resident seasons in [[Sendai]], [[Japan]], on board the [[Cunard Line]]'s [[QE2]] and at the [[Magic Castle]] in [[Hollywood]]. When the Zodiac Brothers split in 1991 and Kieve made plans to attend university an approach from the [[Theatre Royal Stratford East]] to assist with illusions for a production of ''The Invisible Man''<ref name="Rees"/> marked the beginning of a new career as a magic consultant.
==Later career as magic effects creator==
===Stage=== Credits include:
*''[[Groundhog Day (musical)|Groundhog Day: The Musical]]'', on [[August Wilson Theater|Broadway]] and the [[Matthew Warchus]] and [[The Old Vic]] production with music and lyrics by [[Tim Minchin]] features illusions by Kieve. *'"[[Derren Brown]]'s Ghost Train" at [[Thorpe Park]]. Paul worked with Derren Brown and Merlin Magic Making to create some illusions for the attraction opening at [[Thorpe Park]] in May 2016 *''Seeing is Believing'', the [[Dynamo]] live show, UK Tour 2015 *''[[Before the Dawn (Kate Bush)|Before the Dawn]]'', the [[Kate Bush]] concert presented by the KT Fellowship ([[Hammersmith Apollo]], [[London]], 2014) *''[[Macbeth]]'' ([[Park Avenue Armory]], [[New York City|New York]], 2014) *''[[Side Show]]'' ([[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts|Kennedy Center]] and [[St. James Theatre|St James Theatre]], [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], 2014) *''[[Pippin (musical)|Pippin]]'' ([[American Repertory Theatre]], [[Boston]], 2012/13, [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], 2013 and first US national tour, 2014) *''[[Matilda the Musical]]'' ([[West End theatre|West End]] and [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], 2011-current) *''[[Ghost the Musical]]'' ([[West End theatre|West End]] and [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], 2011-2012) *''[[Batman Live]]'' (UK and international arena tours, 2011) *''[[Alice's Adventures in Wonderland (ballet)|Alice's Adventures in Wonderland]]'' ([[The Royal Ballet]], 2011) *''The Invisible Man'' ([[Menier Chocolate Factory]], [[London]], 2010) *''Derren Brown - Svengali'' ([[West End of London|West End]] and UK tour, 2010) *''[[Zorro (musical)|Zorro The Musical]]'', ([[Folies Bergère]], [[Paris]], 2009-10. [[Moscow]], [[Shanghai]], [[Netherlands]], [[West End theatre|West End]], [[London]], [[Atlanta]]) *''Arabian Nights'' ([[Royal Shakespeare Company]], 2009) *''Peter Pan'' ([[Kensington Gardens]], [[London]] 2009) *''L'Heure Espagnole'' ([[Royal Opera House]], [[London]], 2007-2008 *''[[Lord of the Rings (musical)|Lord of the Rings]]'', ([[Toronto]], 2006; [[West End theatre|West End]] 2007-2008) *''Scrooge - The Musical'', [[London Palladium]], [[West End theatre|West End]]. 2007/2008 and 2012/2013 *''Carnesky's Ghost Train'', [[London]], 2005) *''Theatre of Blood'' ([[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]], [[London]], 2005) *''[[Our House (musical)|Our House]]'' ([[West End theatre|West End]], 2003-2004) *''[[Holiday on Ice]]'' (various tours: 2001-2004, 2004-2007, 2006–2009) *''[[Parsifal]]'' ([[Opera National de Paris]], [[Paris]], 1997) *''The Witches'' ([[London]], 1992, 1996 & 2005)
===Film=== Kieve was magic consultant on the 2004 ''[[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (film)|Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban]]'' for which he created a number of 'live' illusions including the floating spheres in the astronomy room and the self-folding marauders map.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Matilda's master illusionist|last=Costa|first=Maddy|newspaper=The Guardian|date=28 November 2011 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2011/nov/28/paul-kieve-illusionist-matilda-hugo}}</ref> He also appears in the film performing [[sleight of hand]] magic making candles multiply in his fingers in the [[Three broomsticks#The Three Broomsticks|Three Broomsticks]]. He is the only real life magician to perform magic in any of the [[Harry Potter (film series)|Harry Potter films]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Q&A Special: Magician Paul Kieve|last=Rees|first=Jasper|website=The Guardian|date=16 July 2011 |url=http://www.theartsdesk.com/theatre/qa-special-magician-paul-kieve}}</ref>
He was magic consultant and instructor on [[Martin Scorsese]]'s 2011 film ''[[Hugo (film)|Hugo]]'', based on the magician and film maker [[Georges Melies|Georges Méliès]]
===Television=== TV credits as magic consultant include: *''[[Luis de Matos]] - Mistérios'', RTP Portugal, 2012 *''[[Return to Cranford|Cranford]]'', 2009 *''For One Night Only'', ITV, 2008 *''[[Legend of Earthsea|Earthsea]]'', 2004 *''Heroes of Magic'', Channel 4, 2004 *''[[Derren Brown#Derren Brown: S.C3.A9ance .282004.29|Derren Brown: Séance]]'', 2004 *''[[Derren Brown#Trick of the Mind .282004.E2.80.932006.29|Derren Brown: Trick of the Mind]]'', 2004 *''The Animal Magic Show'', BBC TV, 2000 *''The Magic of David Copperfield XVI: Unexplained Forces'', 1995
===Work with other illusionists=== Kieve has also acted as magic consultant to [[David Blaine]], [[Arturo Brachetti]], [[Geoffrey Durham]], [[Dynamo (magician)|Dynamo]], [[Jeff McBride]] and [[Dominic Wood]].
===Collaboration with visual and performance artists=== Paul Kieve worked with French artist [[Orlan]] on ''Woman with Head, Woman Without Head'' at [[London]]'s [[Institute of Contemporary Arts]] in 1996 and with multimedia artist [[Christian Jankowski]] on the short film ''The Flock'' in which he also appeared. with video artist [[Jonathan Allen (artist)|Jonathan Allen]] He also created a ghostly dove sequence for the performance art project ''Carnesky's Ghost Train''.
He worked with performance artist Rose English on ''Tantamount Esperance'' at the [[Royal Court Theatre]]<ref name="Herald Soctland">{{cite web | url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/tantamount-esperance-royal-court-london-rose-in-flower-1.499977 |title=Kieve reveals secrets of the spells |last=Woddis |first=Carole |date=8 June 1994 |work=The Herald}}</ref> and has collaborated with Marisa Carnesky on several projects including ''Carnesky's Burlesque Ghost Box'' for [[Duckie (group)|Duckie]] in 2002.
===Other work=== Kieve was magic consultant to Guinness World Records for its 2004 and 2005 magic sections (the only such sections ever carried by the book), researching with other illusionists including [[Penn and Teller]], [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]] and [[Siegfried and Roy]].
==Awards== *[[Drama Desk Award]] for Outstanding Set Design 2012 shared with [[Jon Driscoll]] and Rob Howell for ''[[Ghost the Musical]]'' *British Magical Society's David Berglas Award for Outstanding Contribution to British Magic, 2007 *Guinness World Record in 2003 for quick change costumes in the West End musical ''[[Our House (musical)|Our House]]'' in which the lead character changed costumes 28 times in each performance.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Still Got The Old Magic|last=Johs|first=Ian|newspaper=The Times|date=10 August 2004}}</ref> * Awarded Gold Star membership of The Inner [[The Magic Circle (organisation)|Magic Circle]], London * [[Academy of magical arts#Academy of Magical Arts|Academy of Magical Arts]] Creative Fellowship Award 2013 and Honorary Lifetime Member of The Magic Castle, Hollywood
==Published works== * ''Hocus Pocus: A Tale of Magnificent Magicians'' 2007 (UK), 2008 (US) :A fantasy-biography of sorts including various magic tricks and backstories on some of the world's most famous magicians, along with an introduction by actor [[Daniel Radcliffe]], who Kieve coached during the filming of ''[[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban]]''.
==Stage magic historian== A keen student of the history of magic Kieve regularly lectures both on the history of stage magic and his own work. In 2011 he presented a talk on 'The Magic of Theatre' at the Magic Live conference in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]].<ref>[http://www.magicmagazine.com/live/2011_tuesday.php#schedule "Magic Magazine website"]</ref> He presented ''Grappling with Ghosts: Staging Ghost Effects in the Modern Theatre'' at the [[University of Westminster]]<ref>[http://projects.beyondtext.ac.uk/spiritualismandtechnology/uploads/peppersghostlectures_0910.pdf "PDF on Arts & Humanities Research Council's 'Beyond Text' website"]</ref> in 2009.
He has presented at the Essential Magic Conference - the ground-breaking online magic conference pioneered by Portuguese illusionist [[Luis de Matos]]<ref>[http://essentialmagicconference.com/users/paul-kieve "Profile page at Essential Magic Conference website"]</ref> and has lectured at the [[The Magic Circle (organisation)|Magic Circle]] and the [[Hackney Empire]] in [[London]].
Paul Kieve owns an extensive collection of historical magic memorabilia, some of which he loaned to the [[Hayward Gallery]] for its touring ''Magic Show'' (2009-2010) exhibition. He is a consultant curator of The Magic Circle Museum
==Trivia== Singer-songwriter [[Paloma Faith]] once worked as Paul Kieve's magic assistant.
== References == {{reflist|33em}}
==External links== *[http://www.stageillusion.com Paul Kieve's Official Site] *[http://westmidlands.ideasfactory.com/performance/features/feature40.htm Article on Paul's stage and screen work] *[http://www.scifi.com/earthsea/wizard/flash.html Earthsea's Wizard Certification] - designed by Paul *{{IMDb name|1660519}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070929034027/http://www.lotrfans.co.uk/ Lord of the Rings Stage Show (Illusions and Magic Effects by Paul Kieve) Unofficial Fansite]
{{Navboxes | title = Awards for Paul Kieve | list = {{DramaDesk SetDesign 2001–2025}} {{The Magic Circle - The Maskelyne Award |state=autocollapse}} }}
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Infobox website | name = Polyglot | logo = | screenshot = [[Image:Polyglot v3i12p1.png|Screenshot of Polyglot Volume #3 Issue #12 released in August 2007 announcing the release of [[Dungeons and Dragons]] 4th Edition]] | caption = | url = | commercial = Yes | type = Game Hobby Industry, Computer Games | language = English | registration = | owner = Polymancer Studios, Inc. | author = Polymancer Studios, Inc. | launch date = {{Start date|df=y|2005|3|4}} | current status = Discontinued | revenue = }} '''''Polyglot''''' was a biweekly [[webzine|online newsletter]] about the game hobby industry that ceased publication in 2012. It contains official [[press releases]] put out by [[roleplaying game]], [[board game]], [[Miniature figure (gaming)|miniatures]], [[card game]], [[LARP]], [[comic book]], and [[computer game]] companies. It is published for free as a downloadable [[PDF]]. Polyglot is published by Polymancer Studios, Inc., a Canadian publisher that also prints [[Polymancer magazine]].
It was announced on July 19, 2007, that Polyglot would include [[editorials]] and [[review|product reviews]].<ref>"Polyglot is so successful, we are adding to its features due to readers demands." http://www.thegpa.org/index.php?name=News&file=article&sid=163 Game Publisher Association website, accessed November 1, 2007</ref> The webzine's publisher has not previously endorsed the inclusion of original or editorial content.
In the second anniversary issue (the filename for which indicates it was placed on the company's server on March 8, 2007), the publishers of Polyglot stated that there have been over 600,000 "unique downloads" of Polyglot since March 2005.<ref>''Polyglot'' Volume #3 Issue #1 http://www.polymancerstudios.com/component/option,com_vfm/Itemid,55/do,download/file,PolyGlot|Volume+3|polyglot_volume3_issue1.pdf/</ref> This was stated in the 53rd issue of the webzine (similar press releases have been made [http://www.thegpa.org/index.php?name=News&file=article&sid=126 in other outlets][http://www.enworld.org/showthread.php?t=189044][http://www.gamingreport.com/print.php?sid=23206]) which likely means that the statement was made about the previous 52 issues combined. This equates to roughly 11,538 downloads per issue.
==Format== ''Polyglot'''s issues were numbered in a volume/issue format that is similar to how printed [[magazines]] are numbered; that is, not sequentially. For example, the 27th issue of Polyglot was not "Polyglot issue #27" but "Polyglot Volume #2 Issue #1."
''Polyglot'' was formatted as a US letter size PDF. It is divided into two sections, one for "traditional" games (the term the company uses to describe RPGs, card games, board games, miniatures, etc.) and one for "digital" games. Every page of Polyglot has a banner image of the top containing Polyglot's [[logo]]. There are two different logos, one for the "traditional" gaming section and one for the "digital" gaming section. The front page of each of the two sections has a slightly larger logo. The "traditional" gaming section's logo has the slogan "the language of gaming" and the digital section's logo simply says "digital section." In both sections, the logos have different colors on each page, repeated in sequence (there are 5 different colors for the "traditional" section" and 4 for the "electronic" section).
The first 12 issues of ''Polyglot'' (i.e., Volume #1 Issues #1 to #12) did not have any images in them other than the Polyglot "traditional" section logos. Starting in Volume #1 Issue #13,<ref>''Polyglot'' Volume #1 Issue #13 http://www.polymancerstudios.com/component/option,com_vfm/Itemid,55/do,download/file,PolyGlot|Volume+1|polyglot_volume1_issue13.pdf/</ref> images of games, game company logos, and convention photographs have appeared in the newsletter.
There was no "digital" section in Polyglot until Polyglot Volume #1 issue #25.<ref>''Polyglot'' Volume #1 Issue #25 http://www.polymancerstudios.com/component/option,com_vfm/Itemid,55/do,download/file,PolyGlot|Volume+1|polyglot_volume1_issue25.pdf/</ref> The first computer game press release appeared in the previous issue<ref>''Polyglot'' Volume #1 Issue #24 http://www.polymancerstudios.com/component/option,com_vfm/Itemid,55/do,download/file,PolyGlot|Volume+1|polyglot_volume1_issue24.pdf/</ref> alongside press releases for "traditional" games. A [[table of contents]] first appeared in Volume #1 Issue #25 as well, the first one with clickable [[internal links|internal hyperlinks]] was in Volume #2 Issue #4.<ref>''Polyglot'' Volume #2 Issue #4 http://www.polymancerstudios.com/component/option,com_vfm/Itemid,55/do,download/file,PolyGlot|Volume+2|polyglot_volume2_issue4.pdf/</ref>
Most [[URL]]s in Polyglot press releases are clickable. Many of the items that appear in the newsletter have contact information for the game company or the [[publicist]] who issued the press release. Often (but not always), the writers are [[Attribution (journalism)|attributed]].
As of November 1, 2007, the largest issue of Polyglot to date was Polyglot Volume #3 Issue #9<ref>''Polyglot'' Volume #2 Issue #19 http://www.polymancerstudios.com/component/option,com_vfm/Itemid,55/do,download/file,PolyGlot|Volume+3|polyglot_volume3_issue9.pdf/</ref> at 65 pages.
==Impact== ''Polyglot'' has grown over its history from a 3-page PDF of all text to as large as 65 pages with over 50 press releases and as many as 91 images in Volume #3 Issue #9; the PDF's file size ranges was 5.3 megabytes.<ref>[http://www.polymancerstudios.com/component/option,com_vfm/Itemid,55/do,download/file,PolyGlot|Volume+3|polyglot_volume3_issue9.pdf/ Polymancer Studios Inc. - Offline<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> More than 100 companies (see below) have sent material to Polyglot over the course of the webzine's first 55 issues.
[[Stephen V Cole]] of [[Amarillo Design Bureau Inc.|Starfleet Games]] identified Polyglot as one of the "People Who Will Contact You" in his [[online book]] about how to run a game company. He advises game companies to "ask them to tell you the kind of information they want... and give it to them."<ref>Cole, Stephen V. ''Stephen Cole's Running a Game Publishing Company.'' Amarillo, TX: Amarillo Design Bureau. December 16, 2006. http://www.starfleetgames.com/book/2-the_company.pdf Accessed April 10, 2007.</ref> (The reference is to "Polymancer" but this is incorrect, that being the name of a separate publication by the same company.) Mr. Cole has also stated in his blog that "If you really want to know what's going on in the adventure game industry, you can't do better than" reading Polyglot.<ref>If you want to know, see ... POLYGLOT! February 22, 2007 {{cite web |url=http://www.starfleetgames.com/federation/blog/2007_02_01_archive.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-11-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120913143217/http://www.starfleetgames.com/federation/blog/2007_02_01_archive.html |archivedate=2012-09-13 |df= }} retrieved on November 1, 2007</ref>
Polymancer Studios has encouraged other companies in the game business to adopt professional press release writing techniques such as using the [[inverted pyramid (journalism)|inverted pyramid]] in a [[style guide]] on their web site.<ref>Polymancer Studios, Inc. "The ''Polyglot'' Guide to Press Release Writing for Gaming Professionals" Montreal: Polymancer Studios, Inc. http://www.polymancerstudios.com/documents/HOWTO_Press_Release.pdf{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Accessed November 1, 2007.</ref> A press release by Polymancer Studios in Polyglot Volume #3 Issue #1 indicated that this has had the effect that the company intended.<ref>''Polyglot'' Volume #3 Issue #1 http://www.polymancerstudios.com/component/option,com_vfm/Itemid,55/do,view/file,PolyGlot|Volume+3|polyglot_volume3_issue1.pdf/ page 37: "Not only are we getting ''more'' material to put into ''Polyglot,'' we are also getting ''better'' material because game companies are '''sending us better press releases with each passing week'''." (Original emphasis.)</ref>
Polyglot was distributed freely on other game companies' websites.<ref>Polyglot Volume #1 Issue #14 retrieved from On The Line Games Company website http://www.pizzaboxfootball.com/pressreleases/polyglot_volume1_issue14_2005_09_03%201%20.pdf</ref>
==Regular Contributors== Apart from editorials, Polyglot's only "contributors" are companies in the game industry. Their press releases are often signed by the company's owner or president. However, the computer game companies' press releases are typically signed by third party [[public relations]] and [[marketing]] [[consultants]]. More than 100 companies have sent material to Polyglot since it first went online in March 2005 and as a result a full list of contributors would be long. The companies named below are a partial list.
Roleplaying game companies that have had material posted in Polyglot include [[Wizards of the Coast]], [[White Wolf Publishing|White Wolf]], [[Mongoose Publishing]], [[Columbia Games]], [[Eden Studios]], [[Paizo Publishing]], and a large number of smaller "independent" game companies. Polyglot also regularly has had marketing and publicity material from [[Mayfair Games]] (known for [[Settlers of Catan]]) and other [[German game]] companies. Several miniatures companies also send to Polyglot (usually including color photos of their products) including [[Games Workshop]] and [[Rackham|Rackham Miniatures]]. Traditional wargame companies like [[Amarillo Design Bureau]] and [[Avalanche Press]] also have sent product announcements on a regular basis. Some [[toy]] companies (e.g. Briarpatch), [[Convention (meeting)|conventions]] (e.g. [[Gen Con]]), game industry [[professional associations]] (e.g. [[Game Manufacturers Association|GAMA]], and [[film festivals]] (e.g. [[Fantasia Festival|Fantasia]]) have also had marketing material appear in Polyglot's "Traditional" gaming section.
The various computer games that have been featured in Polyglot include [[Activision]], [[id Software]], [[Electronic Arts]], [[MTV]] (who have a game studio), [[Ubisoft]], and numerous smaller companies. Activision is the most frequent contributor, generally having several press releases, product announcements, and pages of screenshots or video stills placed in every issue of Polyglot (see various issues in the Notes below for examples of this).
==Notes== {{Reflist|colwidth=33em}}
[[Category:Canadian hobby magazines]] [[Category:Defunct magazines of Canada]] [[Category:Game magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 2005]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 2012]] [[Category:Newsletters]] [[Category:Role-playing game magazines]]

{{Refimprove|date=May 2011}} A '''promo''' (a [[shorthand]] term for '''promotion''') is a form of commercial [[advertising]] used in [[broadcast media]], either [[television]] or [[radio]], which promotes a program airing on a television or radio station/network to the viewing or listening audience.
==Background== Promos typically run from 15 to 60 seconds, with 30-second spots being the most common, although some occasionally last run as little as five seconds or as long as 90 seconds. Most promos show select video or audio clips of scenes or segments from an upcoming program (such as a television or radio series, [[film]] or [[television special|special]]). Some television promos (particularly for an upcoming television series) utilize a [[monologue]] format in which a star or host of the program breaks the [[fourth wall]], which is often done in a humorous and/or parodical manner. Most radio promos utilize this format as well, with a host of the program discussing the show itself, though some feature audio clips from past editions of the radio broadcast. [[Terrestrial television|Broadcast]] [[television station]]s promote upcoming newscasts by featuring teases of select story packages to be featured in the broadcast, such as an investigative report or a special-interest feature segment.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kAemy7NwXrQ WLVI The Ten O'Clock News Preview/Promo (1999)]</ref>
The airdate and time of the program's broadcast as well as the name and/or logo of the station or network that the program will be broadcast on are displayed either at the end of or throughout the promo (in the latter case, the airtime and network/station may be displayed before it is mentioned verbally by the [[continuity announcer|announcer]]). Until the mid-1980s on broadcast television stations, the text showing the date and time, along with the station logo were displayed on the bottom of the screen (unlike with broadcast and cable television, airtime information is not pre-displayed on promos for [[broadcast syndication|syndicated programs]] as syndicated programs are typically aired at different times depending on the [[media market|market]], and are instead inserted by the station itself); however, stations now posterize graphics over the tail end of a syndicated program promos where the program's logo is shown (many stations use this treatment on promos for programs airing on networks that the station maintains an affiliation, such as [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] and [[The CW]]) or show the latter portion of the promo within a box surrounded by the graphic.
[[Pay television|Premium cable channels]] and other [[television network]]s that do not accept outside advertising traditionally only air promos during pre-determined breaks that start after a program concludes; the length of these breaks can vary depending on the start time of the succeeding program, it is feasible for multiple program promotions to be shown within the break until the start of the next program. Types of promotional media:- 1) television 2) radio 3) internet 4) billboards 5) newspapers, magazines 6) pamphlets 7) SMS 8) brochures 9) word of mouth
==See also== * [[Advertising]] * [[Promotion (marketing)]] * [[Sponsor (commercial)]] * [[Advertising adstock]] ** [[Radio commercial]] * [[Marketing]] * [[Commercial bumper]] * [[Public service announcement]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Promo (media)}} [[Category:Advertising by medium]] [[Category:Television terminology]] [[Category:Television advertising]] [[Category:Radio terminology]] [[Category:Broadcasting]]
{{tv-stub}}

revision.comment: Edit by [[Special:Contribs/147.147.95.250|147.147.95.250]] has been reverted by [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]] due to possible noncompliance with Wikipedia guidelines. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] (3482871) (Bot)
revision.text:
'''Silly Billy''' was a type of [[clown]] common at [[fair]]s in England during the 19th century. They were also common in London as a [[street entertainer]], along with the similar clown [[Billy Barlow (clown)|Billy Barlow]].<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wN_H-__MBpYC&pg=PA892 |title=The London encyclopaedia |chapter=Street Performers |year=2008 |isbn=978-1-4050-4924-5 |last1=Hibbert |first1=Christopher |last2=Weinreb |first2=Ben |authorlink1=Christopher Hibbert |authorlink2=Ben Weinreb}}</ref> The act included playing the part of a fool or idiot, impersonating a child and singing [[comic song]]s.<ref>{{citation |title=British Plays, Players, and Playing Places |first=B |last=Griffith |journal=The Sewanee Review |year=1997}}</ref> The role was typically played as a [[Stooge (comedian)|stooge]] to another clown.<ref>{{citation |journal=English Dance and Song |publisher=[[English Folk Dance and Song Society]] |year=1973 |quote=The fairground Silly Billy was a comedian's stooge, underdog to his clowning, played as a juvenile part. |page=132}}</ref>
The name is popular because of its nice [[rhyme]]<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_ReuAGJc32UC |title=Words and Names |first=Ernest |last=Weekley |authorlink=Ernest Weekley |page=19 |year=1932 |publisher=Ayer|isbn=978-0-8369-5918-5}}</ref> and was used as a generic nickname for foolish people, especially those named [[William (name)|William]] such as [[Prince William Frederick, Duke of Gloucester and Edinburgh|Prince William Frederick]]<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xvScOaG7mHYC&pg=PA146 |title=A Concise History of the University of Cambridge |first=E. S. |last=Leedham-Green |year=1996 |isbn=978-0-521-43978-7}}</ref> and [[King William IV]].<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_No3oxZfwy4C&pg=PA58 |title=The Houses of Hanover & Saxe-Coburg-Gotha |chapter=William IV |quote=the general opinion was that he was rather a fool – 'Silly Billy' was the inevitable nickname |isbn=978-0-520-22801-6 |last1=Clarke |first1=John |last2=Ridley |first2=Jasper Godwin |last3=Fraser|first3=Antonia |authorlink2=Jasper Ridley|authorlink3=Antonia Fraser|date=2006}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title=Republicanism in Nineteenth Century England |first=N.J. |last=Gossman |journal=International Review of Social History| year=2008 |doi=10.1017/S0020859000002005 |volume=7 |pages=47}}</ref> The nickname was popularised in the 1970s by impressionist [[Mike Yarwood]], putting it in the mouth of the chancellor, [[Denis Healey]], who took the catchphrase up and used it as his own.<ref>{{citation |title=A History of Modern Britain |page=346 |first=Andrew |last=Marr |authorlink=Andrew Marr|publisher=Pan Books |isbn=0330511475 |year=2009}}</ref>
In 1850, the costume of a Silly Billy was short, white trousers with a long white [[pinafore]], white shoes with a strap around the ankle, red sleeves, a [[ruff]] around the neck, and a boy's cap. The hair or wig was arranged to stick out behind the ears. Red makeup was daubed to emphasise the nose with two smears of black for the eyebrows. Multiple pairs of white trousers were needed because women liked to tease the clown by smearing [[gingerbread]] or sticking pins into his legs so that they bled.<ref name=LlLp>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fIoBAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA134 |title=London labour and the London poor |first=Henry |last=Mayhew| authorlink=Henry Mayhew |chapter=Silly Billy |year=1861}}</ref>
Comic routines included a [[mesmerism]] act in which Silly Billy was hypnotised, a parody of a preacher giving a [[sermon]], and a parody of a [[temperance movement|temperance]] campaign.<ref name=LlLp/> Comic songs included ''O'ive getten a Soft Pleace i' my Yead'' and ''Dolly and the Swill Tub''.<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wa_QAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA324 |journal=Chamber's Journal of Popular Literature, Science and Arts |first=William and Robert |last=Chambers |title=The Drama Under Canvas |date=May 27, 1865}}</ref>
The wages of a Silly Billy at the time were about two or three [[Half crown (British coin)|half-crowns]] per day, averaging about a pound a week, over the year. About a dozen performers made their living in this way in the London area.<ref name=LlLp/>
==See also== * [[Commedia dell'arte]]
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
[[Category:Clowns]] [[Category:Nicknames]]
